property.description: The widget to display as drag icon.

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-begin
signal.description: The ::drag-begin signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag is started. It can be used to e.g. set a custom drag icon with gtk_drag_source_set_icon().

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-cancel
signal.description: The ::drag-cancel signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag has failed. The signal handler may handle a failed drag operation based on the type of error. It should return %TRUE if the failure has been handled and the default "drag operation failed" animation should not be shown.

parameter.name: reason
parameter.parameter_description: information on why the drag failed

signal.return: %TRUE if the failed drag operation has been already handled

signal.name: GtkDragSource::drag-end
signal.description: The ::drag-end signal is emitted on the drag source when a drag is finished. A typical reason to connect to this signal is to undo things done in #GtkDragSource::prepare or #GtkDragSource::drag-begin.

parameter.name: delete_data
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the drag was performing %GDK_ACTION_MOVE, and the data should be deleted

signal.name: GtkDragSource::prepare
signal.description: The ::prepare signal is emitted when a drag is about to be initiated. It returns the * #GdkContentProvider to use for the drag that is about to start. The default handler for this signal returns the value of the #GtkDragSource:content property, so if you set up that property ahead of time, you don't need to connect to this signal.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the drag starting point

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate fo the drag starting point

signal.return: a #GdkContentProvider, or %NULL

property.name: GtkDragSource:actions
property.description:
The actions that are supported by drag operations from the source.
Note that you must handle the #GtkDragSource::drag-end signal if the actions include %GDK_ACTION_MOVE.

property.name: GtkDragSource:content
property.description: The data that is offered by drag operations from this source, in the form of a #GdkContentProvider.

signal.name: GtkDrawingArea::resize
signal.description: The ::resize signal is emitted once when the widget is realized, and then each time the widget is changed while realized. This is useful in order to keep state up to date with the widget size, like for instance a backing surface.

property.name: GtkDrawingArea:content-height
property.description: The content height. See gtk_drawing_area_set_content_height() for details.

property.name: GtkDrawingArea:content-width
property.description: The content width. See gtk_drawing_area_set_content_width() for details.

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::enter
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has entered the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::leave
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has left the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkDropControllerMotion::motion
signal.description: Emitted when the pointer moves inside the widget.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:contains-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer of a drag and drop operation is in the controller's widget or a descendant. See also #GtkDropControllerMotion:is-pointer.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before #GtkDropControllerMotion::enter but after #GtkDropControllerMotion::leave is emitted.

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:drop
property.description:
The ongoing drop operation over the controller's widget or its descendant. If no drop operation is going on, this property returns %NULL.
The event controller should not modify the @drop, but it might want to query its properties.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before #GtkDropControllerMotion::enter but after #GtkDropControllerMotion::leave is emitted.

property.name: GtkDropControllerMotion:is-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget itself, as opposed to in a descendent widget. See also #GtkDropControllerMotion:contains-pointer.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before #GtkDropControllerMotion::enter but after #GtkDropControllerMotion::leave is emitted.

property.name: GtkDropDown:enable-search
property.description:
Whether to show a search entry in the popup.
Note that search requires #GtkDropDown:expression to be set.

property.name: GtkDropDown:expression
property.description: An expression to evaluate to obtain strings to match against the search term (see #GtkDropDown:enable-search). If #GtkDropDown:factory is not set, the expression is also used to bind strings to labels produced by a default factory.

property.name: GtkDropDown:factory
property.description: Factory for populating list items.

property.name: GtkDropDown:list-factory
property.description:
The factory for populating list items in the popup.
If this is not set, #GtkDropDown:factory is used.

property.name: GtkDropDown:model
property.description: Model for the displayed items.

property.name: GtkDropDown:selected
property.description: The position of the selected item in #GtkDropDown:model, or #GTK_INVALID_LIST_POSITION if no item is selected.

property.name: GtkDropDown:selected-item
property.description: The selected item.

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::accept
signal.description:
The ::accept signal is emitted on the drop site when a drop operation is about to begin. If the drop is not accepted, %FALSE will be returned and the drop target will ignore the drop. If %TRUE is returned, the drop is accepted for now but may be rejected later via a call to gtk_drop_target_reject() or ultimately by returning %FALSE from GtkDropTarget::drop
The default handler for this signal decides whether to accept the drop based on the formats provided by the @drop.
If the decision whether the drop will be accepted or rejected needs inspecting the data, this function should return %TRUE, the GtkDropTarget:preload property should be set and the value should be inspected via the GObject::notify:value signal and then call gtk_drop_target_reject().
signal.return: %TRUE if @drop is accepted

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::drop
signal.description:
The ::drop signal is emitted on the drop site when the user drops the data onto the widget. The signal handler must determine whether the pointer position is in a drop zone or not. If it is not in a drop zone, it returns %FALSE and no further processing is necessary.
Otherwise, the handler returns %TRUE. In this case, this handler will accept the drop. The handler is responsible for rading the given @value and performing the drop operation.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: whether the drop was accepted at the given pointer position

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::enter
signal.description: The ::enter signal is emitted on the drop site when the pointer enters the widget. It can be used to set up custom highlighting.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation or 0 if dropping is not supported at the current @x,@y location.

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::leave
signal.description: The ::leave signal is emitted on the drop site when the pointer leaves the widget. Its main purpose it to undo things done in #GtkDropTarget::enter.

signal.name: GtkDropTarget::motion
signal.description: The ::motion signal is emitted while the pointer is moving over the drop target.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation or 0 if dropping is not supported at the current @x,@y location.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:actions
property.description: The #GdkDragActions that this drop target supports

property.name: GtkDropTarget:drop
property.description: The #GdkDrop that is currently being performed

property.name: GtkDropTarget:formats
property.description: The #GdkContentFormats that determine the supported data formats

property.name: GtkDropTarget:preload
property.description:
Whether the drop data should be preloaded when the pointer is only hovering over the widget but has not been released.
Setting this property allows finer grained reaction to an ongoing drop at the cost of loading more data.
The default value for this property is %FALSE to avoid downloading huge amounts of data by accident. For example, if somebody drags a full document of gigabytes of text from a text editor across a widget with a preloading drop target, this data will be downloaded, even if the data is ultimately dropped elsewhere.
For a lot of data formats, the amount of data is very small (like %GDK_TYPE_RGBA), so enabling this property does not hurt at all. And for local-only drag'n'drop operations, no data transfer is done, so enabling it there is free.

property.name: GtkDropTarget:value
property.description:
The value for this drop operation or %NULL if the data has not been loaded yet or no drop operation is going on.
Data may be available before the GtkDropTarget::drop signal gets emitted - for example when the GtkDropTarget:preload property is set. You can use the GObject::notify signal to be notified of available data.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::accept
signal.description:
The ::accept signal is emitted on the drop site when a drop operation is about to begin.
If the drop is not accepted, %FALSE will be returned and the drop target will ignore the drop. If %TRUE is returned, the drop is accepted for now but may be rejected later via a call to gtk_drop_target_async_reject() or ultimately by returning %FALSE from #GtkDropTargetAsync::drop.
The default handler for this signal decides whether to accept the drop based on the formats provided by the @drop.
If the decision whether the drop will be accepted or rejected needs further processing, such as inspecting the data, this function should return %TRUE and proceed as is @drop was accepted and if it decides to reject the drop later, it should call gtk_drop_target_async_reject_drop().
signal.return: %TRUE if @drop is accepted

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-enter
signal.description: The ::drag-enter signal is emitted on the drop site when the pointer enters the widget. It can be used to set up custom highlighting.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-leave
signal.description: The ::drag-leave signal is emitted on the drop site when the pointer leaves the widget. Its main purpose it to undo things done in #GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-enter.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drag-motion
signal.description: The ::drag-motion signal is emitted while the pointer is moving over the drop target.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: Preferred action for this drag operation.

signal.name: GtkDropTargetAsync::drop
signal.description:
The ::drop signal is emitted on the drop site when the user drops the data onto the widget. The signal handler must determine whether the pointer position is in a drop zone or not. If it is not in a drop zone, it returns %FALSE and no further processing is necessary.
Otherwise, the handler returns %TRUE. In this case, this handler will accept the drop. The handler must ensure that gdk_drop_finish() is called to let the source know that the drop is done. The call to gdk_drop_finish() must only be done when all data has been received.
To receive the data, use one of the read functions provides by #GdkDrop such as gdk_drop_read_async() or gdk_drop_read_value_async().

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the x coordinate of the current pointer position

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the y coordinate of the current pointer position

signal.return: whether the drop is accepted at the given pointer position

property.name: GtkDropTargetAsync:actions
property.description: The #GdkDragActions that this drop target supports

property.name: GtkDropTargetAsync:formats
property.description: The #GdkContentFormats that determines the supported data formats

signal.name: GtkEditable::changed
signal.description:
The ::changed signal is emitted at the end of a single user-visible operation on the contents of the #GtkEditable.
E.g., a paste operation that replaces the contents of the selection will cause only one signal emission (even though it is implemented by first deleting the selection, then inserting the new content, and may cause multiple ::notify::text signals to be emitted).

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::delete-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted when text is deleted from the widget by the user. The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for deleting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the range of deleted text, or prevent it from being deleted entirely. The @start_pos and @end_pos parameters are interpreted as for gtk_editable_delete_text().

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEditable::insert-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted when text is inserted into the widget by the user. The default handler for this signal will normally be responsible for inserting the text, so by connecting to this signal and then stopping the signal with g_signal_stop_emission(), it is possible to modify the inserted text, or prevent it from being inserted entirely.

parameter.name: editable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the new text, in bytes, or -1 if new_text is nul-terminated

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position, in characters, at which to insert the new text. this is an in-out parameter. After the signal emission is finished, it should point after the newly inserted text.

property.name: GtkEditableLabel:editing
property.description: This property is %TRUE while the widget is in edit mode.

signal.name: GtkEmojiChooser::emoji-picked
signal.description: The ::emoji-picked signal is emitted when the user selects an Emoji.

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the Unicode sequence for the picked Emoji, in UTF-8

signal.name: GtkEntry::activate
signal.description: The ::activate signal is forwarded from the #GtkText::activated signal, which is a keybinding signal for all forms of the Enter key.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: The widget on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-press
signal.description: The ::icon-press signal is emitted when an activatable icon is clicked.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

signal.name: GtkEntry::icon-release
signal.description: The ::icon-release signal is emitted on the button release from a mouse click over an activatable icon.

parameter.name: entry
parameter.parameter_description: The entry on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: icon_pos
parameter.parameter_description: The position of the clicked icon

signal.name: GtkEntry::show-emoji-icon
signal.description: When this is %TRUE, the entry will show an emoji icon in the secondary icon position that brings up the Emoji chooser when clicked.

signal.name: GtkEntry::tabs
signal.description: A list of tabstops to apply to the text of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:attributes
property.description:
A list of Pango attributes to apply to the text of the entry.
This is mainly useful to change the size or weight of the text.
The #PangoAttribute's @start_index and @end_index must refer to the #GtkEntryBuffer text, i.e. without the preedit string.

property.name: GtkEntry:completion
property.description: The auxiliary completion object to use with the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:extra-menu
property.description: A menu model whose contents will be appended to the context menu.

property.name: GtkEntry:im-module
property.description:
Which IM (input method) module should be used for this entry. See #GtkIMContext.
Setting this to a non-%NULL value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the GtkSettings #GtkSettings:gtk-im-module property.

property.name: GtkEntry:input-hints
property.description: Additional hints (beyond #GtkEntry:input-purpose) that allow input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.

property.name: GtkEntry:input-purpose
property.description:
The purpose of this text field.
This property can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.
Note that setting the purpose to %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PASSWORD or %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PIN is independent from setting #GtkEntry:visibility.

property.name: GtkEntry:invisible-char-set
property.description: Whether the invisible char has been set for the #GtkEntry.

property.name: GtkEntry:overwrite-mode
property.description: If text is overwritten when typing in the #GtkEntry.

property.name: GtkEntry:placeholder-text
property.description: The text that will be displayed in the #GtkEntry when it is empty and unfocused.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-activatable
property.description:
Whether the primary icon is activatable.
GTK emits the #GtkEntry::icon-press and #GtkEntry::icon-release signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.
Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-gicon
property.description: The #GIcon to use for the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-name
property.description: The icon name to use for the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-paintable
property.description: A #GdkPaintable to use as the primary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-sensitive
property.description:
Whether the primary icon is sensitive.
An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK does not emit the #GtkEntry::icon-press and #GtkEntry::icon-release signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.
An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-storage-type
property.description: The representation which is used for the primary icon of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-tooltip-markup
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon, which is marked up with the [Pango text markup language][PangoMarkupFormat].
Also see gtk_entry_set_icon_tooltip_markup().

property.name: GtkEntry:primary-icon-tooltip-text
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the primary icon.
Also see gtk_entry_set_icon_tooltip_text().

property.name: GtkEntry:progress-fraction
property.description: The current fraction of the task that's been completed.

property.name: GtkEntry:progress-pulse-step
property.description: The fraction of total entry width to move the progress bouncing block for each call to gtk_entry_progress_pulse().

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-activatable
property.description:
Whether the secondary icon is activatable.
GTK emits the #GtkEntry::icon-press and #GtkEntry::icon-release signals only on sensitive, activatable icons.
Sensitive, but non-activatable icons can be used for purely informational purposes.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-gicon
property.description: The #GIcon to use for the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-name
property.description: The icon name to use for the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-paintable
property.description: A #GdkPaintable to use as the secondary icon for the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-sensitive
property.description:
Whether the secondary icon is sensitive.
An insensitive icon appears grayed out. GTK does not emit the #GtkEntry::icon-press and #GtkEntry::icon-release signals and does not allow DND from insensitive icons.
An icon should be set insensitive if the action that would trigger when clicked is currently not available.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-storage-type
property.description: The representation which is used for the secondary icon of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-tooltip-markup
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon, which is marked up with the [Pango text markup language][PangoMarkupFormat].
Also see gtk_entry_set_icon_tooltip_markup().

property.name: GtkEntry:secondary-icon-tooltip-text
property.description:
The contents of the tooltip on the secondary icon.
Also see gtk_entry_set_icon_tooltip_text().

property.name: GtkEntry:text-length
property.description: The length of the text in the #GtkEntry.

property.name: GtkEntry:truncate-multiline
property.description: When %TRUE, pasted multi-line text is truncated to the first line.

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::deleted-text
signal.description: The text is altered in the default handler for this signal. If you want access to the text after the text has been modified, use %G_CONNECT_AFTER.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was deleted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were deleted.

signal.name: GtkEntryBuffer::inserted-text
signal.description: This signal is emitted after text is inserted into the buffer.

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position the text was inserted at.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: The number of characters that were inserted.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:length
property.description: The length (in characters) of the text in buffer.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:max-length
property.description: The maximum length (in characters) of the text in the buffer.

property.name: GtkEntryBuffer:text
property.description: The contents of the buffer.

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::cursor-on-match
signal.description:
Gets emitted when a match from the cursor is on a match of the list. The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to gtk_entry_completion_set_model().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreeIter positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::insert-prefix
signal.description:
Gets emitted when the inline autocompletion is triggered. The default behaviour is to make the entry display the whole prefix and select the newly inserted part.
Applications may connect to this signal in order to insert only a smaller part of the @prefix into the entry - e.g. the entry used in the #GtkFileChooser inserts only the part of the prefix up to the next '/'.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: prefix
parameter.parameter_description: the common prefix of all possible completions

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::match-selected
signal.description:
Gets emitted when a match from the list is selected. The default behaviour is to replace the contents of the entry with the contents of the text column in the row pointed to by @iter.
Note that @model is the model that was passed to gtk_entry_completion_set_model().

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreeIter positioned at the selected match

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal has been handled

signal.name: GtkEntryCompletion::no-matches
signal.description: Gets emitted when the filter model has zero number of rows in completion_complete method. (In other words when GtkEntryCompletion is out of suggestions)

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:cell-area
property.description:
The #GtkCellArea used to layout cell renderers in the treeview column.
If no area is specified when creating the entry completion with gtk_entry_completion_new_with_area() a horizontally oriented #GtkCellAreaBox will be used.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:inline-completion
property.description: Determines whether the common prefix of the possible completions should be inserted automatically in the entry. Note that this requires text-column to be set, even if you are using a custom match function.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:inline-selection
property.description: Determines whether the possible completions on the popup will appear in the entry as you navigate through them.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-completion
property.description: Determines whether the possible completions should be shown in a popup window.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-set-width
property.description: Determines whether the completions popup window will be resized to the width of the entry.

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:popup-single-match
property.description: Determines whether the completions popup window will shown for a single possible completion. You probably want to set this to %FALSE if you are using [inline completion][GtkEntryCompletion--inline-completion].

property.name: GtkEntryCompletion:text-column
property.description: The column of the model containing the strings. Note that the strings must be UTF-8.

enum.name: GtkEntryIconPosition
enum.description: Specifies the side of the entry at which an icon is placed.

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_PRIMARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the beginning of the entry (depending on the text direction).

parameter.name: GTK_ENTRY_ICON_SECONDARY
parameter.parameter_description: At the end of the entry (depending on the text direction).

property.name: GtkEventController:name
property.description: The name for this controller, typically used for debugging purposes.

property.name: GtkEventController:propagation-limit
property.description: The limit for which events this controller will handle.

property.name: GtkEventController:propagation-phase
property.description: The propagation phase at which this controller will handle events.

property.name: GtkEventController:widget
property.description: The widget receiving the #GdkEvents that the controller will handle.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerFocus::enter
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever the focus enters into the widget or one of its descendents.
Note that this means you may not get an ::enter signal even though the widget becomes the focus location, in certain cases (such as when the focus moves from a descendent of the widget to the widget itself). If you are interested in these cases, you can monitor the #GtkEventControllerFocus:is-focus property for changes.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerFocus::leave
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever the focus leaves the widget hierarchy that is rooted at the widget that the controller is attached to.
Note that this means you may not get a ::leave signal even though the focus moves away from the widget, in certain cases (such as when the focus moves from the widget to a descendent). If you are interested in these cases, you can monitor the #GtkEventControllerFocus:is-focus property for changes.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerFocus:contains-focus
property.description:
Whether focus is contain in the controllers widget. See See #GtkEventControllerFocus:is-focus for whether the focus is in the widget itself or inside a descendent.
When handling focus events, this property is updated before #GtkEventControllerFocus::enter or #GtkEventControllerFocus::leave are emitted.

property.name: GtkEventControllerFocus:is-focus
property.description:
Whether focus is in the controllers widget itself, opposed to in a descendent widget. See also #GtkEventControllerFocus:contains-focus.
When handling focus events, this property is updated before #GtkEventControllerFocus::enter or #GtkEventControllerFocus::leave are emitted.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::im-update
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the input method context filters away a keypress and prevents the @controller receiving it. See gtk_event_controller_key_set_im_context() and gtk_im_context_filter_keypress().

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::key-pressed
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a key is pressed.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: keycode
parameter.parameter_description: the raw code of the pressed key.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons. See #GdkModifierType.

signal.return: %TRUE if the key press was handled, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::key-released
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a key is released.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: keycode
parameter.parameter_description: the raw code of the released key.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons. See #GdkModifierType.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerKey::modifiers
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the state of modifier keys and pointer buttons change.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the bitmask, representing the new state of modifier keys and pointer buttons. See #GdkModifierType.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerLegacy::event
signal.description: Emitted for each GDK event delivered to @controller.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event and the emission of this signal. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::enter
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has entered the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::leave
signal.description: Signals that the pointer has left the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerMotion::motion
signal.description: Emitted when the pointer moves inside the widget.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerMotion:contains-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget or a descendant. See also #GtkEventControllerMotion:is-pointer.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before #GtkEventControllerMotion::enter but after #GtkEventControllerMotion::leave is emitted.

property.name: GtkEventControllerMotion:is-pointer
property.description:
Whether the pointer is in the controllers widget itself, as opposed to in a descendent widget. See also #GtkEventControllerMotion:contains-pointer.
When handling crossing events, this property is updated before #GtkEventControllerMotion::enter but after #GtkEventControllerMotion::leave is emitted.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::decelerate
signal.description: Emitted after scroll is finished if the #GTK_EVENT_CONTROLLER_SCROLL_KINETIC flag is set. @vel_x and @vel_y express the initial velocity that was imprinted by the scroll events. @vel_x and @vel_y are expressed in pixels/ms.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll
signal.description: Signals that the widget should scroll by the amount specified by @dx and @dy.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.return: %TRUE if the scroll event was handled, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll-begin
signal.description: Signals that a new scrolling operation has begun. It will only be emitted on devices capable of it.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

signal.name: GtkEventControllerScroll::scroll-end
signal.description: Signals that a new scrolling operation has finished. It will only be emitted on devices capable of it.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: The object that received the signal

property.name: GtkEventControllerScroll:flags
property.description: The flags affecting event controller behavior

enum.name: GtkEventControllerScrollFlags
enum.description: Describes the behavior of a #GtkEventControllerScroll.

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_CONTROLLER_SCROLL_DISCRETE
parameter.parameter_description: Only emit deltas that are multiples of 1.

enum.name: GtkEventSequenceState
enum.description: Describes the state of a #GdkEventSequence in a #GtkGesture.

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_SEQUENCE_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: The sequence is handled, but not grabbed.

parameter.name: GTK_EVENT_SEQUENCE_CLAIMED
parameter.parameter_description: The sequence is handled and grabbed.

signal.name: GtkExpander::activate
signal.description: Activates the #GtkExpander.

property.name: GtkExpander:resize-toplevel
property.description: When this property is %TRUE, the expander will resize the toplevel widget containing the expander upon expanding and collapsing.

property.name: GtkFileChooser:create-folders
property.description: Whether a file chooser not in %GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN mode will offer the user to create new folders.

property.name: GtkFileChooser:filters
property.description:
A #GListModel containing the filters that have been added with gtk_file_chooser_add_filter().
The returned object should not be modified. It may or may not be updated for later changes.

property.name: GtkFileChooser:shortcut-folders
property.description:
A #GListModel containing the shortcut folders that have been added with gtk_file_chooser_add_shortcut_folder().
The returned object should not be modified. It may or may not be updated for later changes.

enum.name: GtkFileChooserAction
enum.description: Describes whether a #GtkFileChooser is being used to open existing files or to save to a possibly new file.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates open mode. The file chooser will only let the user pick an existing file.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_SAVE
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates save mode. The file chooser will let the user pick an existing file, or type in a new filename.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_SELECT_FOLDER
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an Open mode for selecting folders. The file chooser will let the user pick an existing folder.

enum.name: GtkFileChooserError
enum.description: These identify the various errors that can occur while calling #GtkFileChooser functions.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_NONEXISTENT
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates that a file does not exist.

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates a duplicate path (e.g. when adding a bookmark).

parameter.name: GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ERROR_INCOMPLETE_HOSTNAME
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an incomplete hostname (e.g. "http://foo" without a slash after that).

property.name: GtkFileChooserNative:accept-label
property.description: The text used for the label on the accept button in the dialog, or %NULL to use the default text.

property.name: GtkFileChooserNative:cancel-label
property.description: The text used for the label on the cancel button in the dialog, or %NULL to use the default text.

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::desktop-folder
signal.description:
The ::desktop-folder signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show the user's Desktop folder in the file list.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + D`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::down-folder
signal.description:
The ::down-folder signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser go to a child of the current folder in the file hierarchy. The subfolder that will be used is displayed in the path bar widget of the file chooser. For example, if the path bar is showing "/foo/bar/baz", with bar currently displayed, then this will cause the file chooser to switch to the "baz" subfolder.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + Down`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::home-folder
signal.description:
The ::home-folder signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show the user's home folder in the file list.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + Home`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::location-popup
signal.description:
The ::location-popup signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show a "Location" prompt which the user can use to manually type the name of the file he wishes to select.
The default bindings for this signal are `Control + L` with a @path string of "" (the empty string). It is also bound to `/` with a @path string of "`/`" (a slash): this lets you type `/` and immediately type a path name. On Unix systems, this is bound to `~` (tilde) with a @path string of "~" itself for access to home directories.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a string that gets put in the text entry for the file name

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::location-popup-on-paste
signal.description:
The ::location-popup-on-paste signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show a "Location" prompt when the user pastes into a #GtkFileChooserWidget.
The default binding for this signal is `Control + V`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::location-toggle-popup
signal.description:
The ::location-toggle-popup signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to toggle the visibility of a "Location" prompt which the user can use to manually type the name of the file he wishes to select.
The default binding for this signal is `Control + L`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::places-shortcut
signal.description:
The ::places-shortcut signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to move the focus to the places sidebar.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + P`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::quick-bookmark
signal.description:
The ::quick-bookmark signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser switch to the bookmark specified in the @bookmark_index parameter. For example, if you have three bookmarks, you can pass 0, 1, 2 to this signal to switch to each of them, respectively.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + 1`, `Alt + 2`, etc. until `Alt + 0`. Note that in the default binding, that `Alt + 1` is actually defined to switch to the bookmark at index 0, and so on successively; `Alt + 0` is defined to switch to the bookmark at index 10.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: bookmark_index
parameter.parameter_description: the number of the bookmark to switch to

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::recent-shortcut
signal.description:
The ::recent-shortcut signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show the Recent location.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + R`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::search-shortcut
signal.description:
The ::search-shortcut signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser show the search entry.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + S`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::show-hidden
signal.description:
The ::show-hidden signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser display hidden files.
The default binding for this signal is `Control + H`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkFileChooserWidget::up-folder
signal.description:
The ::up-folder signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
This is used to make the file chooser go to the parent of the current folder in the file hierarchy.
The default binding for this signal is `Alt + Up`.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkFileFilter:name
property.description:
The human-readable name of the filter.
This is the string that will be displayed in the file selector user interface if there is a selectable list of filters.

signal.name: GtkFilter::changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever the filter changed. Users of the filter should then check items again via gtk_filter_match().
#GtkFilterListModel handles this signal automatically.
Depending on the @change parameter, not all items need to be changed, but only some. Refer to the #GtkFilterChange documentation for details.

enum.name: GtkFilterChange
enum.description:
Describes changes in a filter in more detail and allows objects using the filter to optimize refiltering items.
If you are writing an implementation and are not sure which value to pass, %GTK_FILTER_CHANGE_DIFFERENT is always a correct choice.

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_CHANGE_DIFFERENT
parameter.parameter_description: The filter change cannot be described with any of the other enumeration values.

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_CHANGE_LESS_STRICT
parameter.parameter_description: The filter is less strict than it was before: All items that it used to return %TRUE for still return %TRUE, others now may, too.

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_CHANGE_MORE_STRICT
parameter.parameter_description: The filter is more strict than it was before: All items that it used to return %FALSE for still return %FALSE, others now may, too.

property.name: GtkFilterListModel:filter
property.description: The filter for this model

property.name: GtkFilterListModel:incremental
property.description: If the model should filter items incrementally

property.name: GtkFilterListModel:model
property.description: The model being filtered

property.name: GtkFilterListModel:pending
property.description: Number of items not yet filtered

enum.name: GtkFilterMatch
enum.description:
Describes the known strictness of a filter.
Note that for filters where the strictness is not known, %GTK_FILTER_MATCH_SOME is always an acceptable value, even if a filter does match all or no items.

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_MATCH_SOME
parameter.parameter_description: The filter matches some items, gtk_filter_match() may return %TRUE or %FALSE

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_MATCH_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: The filter does not match any item, gtk_filter_match() will always return %FALSE.

parameter.name: GTK_FILTER_MATCH_ALL
parameter.parameter_description: The filter matches all items, gtk_filter_match() will alays return %TRUE.

property.name: GtkFlattenListModel:model
property.description: The model being flattened

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::activate-cursor-child
signal.description: The ::activate-cursor-child signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user activates the @box.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::child-activated
signal.description: The ::child-activated signal is emitted when a child has been activated by the user.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifier does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. - Arrow keys move by individual children - Home/End keys move to the ends of the box - PageUp/PageDown keys move vertically by pages

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity fo the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::select-all
signal.description:
The ::select-all signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to select all children of the box, if the selection mode permits it.
The default bindings for this signal is Ctrl-a.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::selected-children-changed
signal.description:
The ::selected-children-changed signal is emitted when the set of selected children changes.
Use gtk_flow_box_selected_foreach() or gtk_flow_box_get_selected_children() to obtain the selected children.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::toggle-cursor-child
signal.description:
The ::toggle-cursor-child signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which toggles the selection of the child that has the focus.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Space.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFlowBox::unselect-all
signal.description:
The ::unselect-all signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to unselect all children of the box, if the selection mode permits it.
The default bindings for this signal is Ctrl-Shift-a.

parameter.name: box
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkFlowBox on which the signal is emitted

property.name: GtkFlowBox:activate-on-single-click
property.description: Determines whether children can be activated with a single click, or require a double-click.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:column-spacing
property.description: The amount of horizontal space between two children.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:homogeneous
property.description: Determines whether all children should be allocated the same size.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:max-children-per-line
property.description: The maximum amount of children to request space for consecutively in the given orientation.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:min-children-per-line
property.description:
The minimum number of children to allocate consecutively in the given orientation.
Setting the minimum children per line ensures that a reasonably small height will be requested for the overall minimum width of the box.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:row-spacing
property.description: The amount of vertical space between two children.

property.name: GtkFlowBox:selection-mode
property.description: The selection mode used by the flow box.

signal.name: GtkFlowBoxChild::activate
signal.description:
The ::activate signal is emitted when the user activates a child widget in a #GtkFlowBox, either by clicking or double-clicking, or by using the Space or Enter key.
While this signal is used as a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction], it can be used by applications for their own purposes.

parameter.name: child
parameter.parameter_description: The child on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkFontButton::font-set
signal.description:
The ::font-set signal is emitted when the user selects a font. When handling this signal, use gtk_font_chooser_get_font() to find out which font was just selected.
Note that this signal is only emitted when the user changes the font. If you need to react to programmatic font changes as well, use the notify::font signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

property.name: GtkFontButton:title
property.description: The title of the font chooser dialog.

property.name: GtkFontButton:use-font
property.description: If this property is set to %TRUE, the label will be drawn in the selected font.

property.name: GtkFontButton:use-size
property.description: If this property is set to %TRUE, the label will be drawn with the selected font size.

signal.name: GtkFontChooser::font-activated
signal.description: Emitted when a font is activated. This usually happens when the user double clicks an item, or an item is selected and the user presses one of the keys Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkFontChooser:font
property.description: The font description as a string, e.g. "Sans Italic 12".

property.name: GtkFontChooser:font-desc
property.description: The font description as a #PangoFontDescription.

property.name: GtkFontChooser:font-features
property.description: The selected font features, in a format that is compatible with CSS and with Pango attributes.

property.name: GtkFontChooser:language
property.description: The language for which the #GtkFontChooser:font-features were selected, in a format that is compatible with CSS and with Pango attributes.

property.name: GtkFontChooser:level
property.description: The level of granularity to offer for selecting fonts.

property.name: GtkFontChooser:preview-text
property.description: The string with which to preview the font.

property.name: GtkFontChooser:show-preview-entry
property.description: Whether to show an entry to change the preview text.

enum.name: GtkFontChooserLevel
enum.description:
This enumeration specifies the granularity of font selection that is desired in a font chooser.
This enumeration may be extended in the future; applications should ignore unknown values.

parameter.name: GTK_FONT_CHOOSER_LEVEL_STYLE
parameter.parameter_description: Allow selecting a specific font face

parameter.name: GTK_FONT_CHOOSER_LEVEL_SIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Allow selecting a specific font size

parameter.name: GTK_FONT_CHOOSER_LEVEL_VARIATIONS
parameter.parameter_description: Allow changing OpenType font variation axes

parameter.name: GTK_FONT_CHOOSER_LEVEL_FEATURES
parameter.parameter_description: Allow selecting specific OpenType font features

property.name: GtkFontChooserWidget:tweak-action
property.description:
A toggle action that can be used to switch to the tweak page of the font chooser widget, which lets the user tweak the OpenType features and variation axes of the selected font.
The action will be enabled or disabled depending on whether the selected font has any features or axes.

signal.name: GtkGLArea::create-context
signal.description:
The ::create-context signal is emitted when the widget is being realized, and allows you to override how the GL context is created. This is useful when you want to reuse an existing GL context, or if you want to try creating different kinds of GL options.
If context creation fails then the signal handler can use gtk_gl_area_set_error() to register a more detailed error of how the construction failed.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure

signal.return: a newly created #GdkGLContext; the #GtkGLArea widget will take ownership of the returned value.

signal.name: GtkGLArea::render
signal.description:
The ::render signal is emitted every time the contents of the #GtkGLArea should be redrawn.
The @context is bound to the @area prior to emitting this function, and the buffers are painted to the window once the emission terminates.
signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %FALSE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkGLArea::resize
signal.description:
The ::resize signal is emitted once when the widget is realized, and then each time the widget is changed while realized. This is useful in order to keep GL state up to date with the widget size, like for instance camera properties which may depend on the width/height ratio.
The GL context for the area is guaranteed to be current when this signal is emitted.
The default handler sets up the GL viewport.

property.name: GtkGLArea:auto-render
property.description:
If set to %TRUE the #GtkGLArea::render signal will be emitted every time the widget draws. This is the default and is useful if drawing the widget is faster.
If set to %FALSE the data from previous rendering is kept around and will be used for drawing the widget the next time, unless the window is resized. In order to force a rendering gtk_gl_area_queue_render() must be called. This mode is useful when the scene changes seldom, but takes a long time to redraw.

property.name: GtkGLArea:context
property.description:
The #GdkGLContext used by the #GtkGLArea widget.
The #GtkGLArea widget is responsible for creating the #GdkGLContext instance. If you need to render with other kinds of buffers (stencil, depth, etc), use render buffers.

property.name: GtkGLArea:has-depth-buffer
property.description: If set to %TRUE the widget will allocate and enable a depth buffer for the target framebuffer.

property.name: GtkGLArea:has-stencil-buffer
property.description: If set to %TRUE the widget will allocate and enable a stencil buffer for the target framebuffer.

property.name: GtkGLArea:use-es
property.description:
If set to %TRUE the widget will try to create a #GdkGLContext using OpenGL ES instead of OpenGL.
See also: gdk_gl_context_set_use_es()

signal.name: GtkGesture::begin
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the gesture is recognized. This means the number of touch sequences matches #GtkGesture:n-points.
Note: These conditions may also happen when an extra touch (eg. a third touch on a 2-touches gesture) is lifted, in that situation @sequence won't pertain to the current set of active touches, so don't rely on this being true.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: sequence
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkEventSequence that made the gesture to be recognized

signal.name: GtkGesture::cancel
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever a sequence is cancelled. This usually happens on active touches when gtk_event_controller_reset() is called on @gesture (manually, due to grabs...), or the individual @sequence was claimed by parent widgets' controllers (see gtk_gesture_set_sequence_state()).
@gesture must forget everything about @sequence as a reaction to this signal.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkGesture::end
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when @gesture either stopped recognizing the event sequences as something to be handled, or the number of touch sequences became higher or lower than #GtkGesture:n-points.
Note: @sequence might not pertain to the group of sequences that were previously triggering recognition on @gesture (ie. a just pressed touch sequence that exceeds #GtkGesture:n-points). This situation may be detected by checking through gtk_gesture_handles_sequence().

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: sequence
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkEventSequence that made gesture recognition to finish

signal.name: GtkGesture::sequence-state-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a sequence state changes. See gtk_gesture_set_sequence_state() to know more about the expectable sequence lifetimes.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkGesture::update
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever an event is handled while the gesture is recognized. @sequence is guaranteed to pertain to the set of active touches.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkGesture:n-points
property.description: The number of touch points that trigger recognition on this gesture,

signal.name: GtkGestureClick::pressed
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a button or touch press happens.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: n_press
parameter.parameter_description: how many touch/button presses happened with this one

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: The X coordinate, in widget allocation coordinates

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: The Y coordinate, in widget allocation coordinates

signal.name: GtkGestureClick::released
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a button or touch is released. @n_press will report the number of press that is paired to this event, note that #GtkGestureClick::stopped may have been emitted between the press and its release, @n_press will only start over at the next press.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: n_press
parameter.parameter_description: number of press that is paired with this release

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: The X coordinate, in widget allocation coordinates

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: The Y coordinate, in widget allocation coordinates

signal.name: GtkGestureClick::stopped
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever any time/distance threshold has been exceeded.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkGestureClick::unpaired-release
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the gesture receives a release event that had no previous corresponding press. Due to implicit grabs, this can only happen on situations where input is grabbed elsewhere mid-press or the pressed widget voluntarily relinquishes its implicit grab.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkGestureDrag::drag-begin
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever dragging starts.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start_x
parameter.parameter_description: X coordinate, relative to the widget allocation

parameter.name: start_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y coordinate, relative to the widget allocation

signal.name: GtkGestureDrag::drag-end
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the dragging is finished.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: X offset, relative to the start point

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y offset, relative to the start point

signal.name: GtkGestureDrag::drag-update
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the dragging point moves.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: X offset, relative to the start point

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: Y offset, relative to the start point

signal.name: GtkGestureLongPress::cancelled
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a press moved too far, or was released before #GtkGestureLongPress::pressed happened.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkGestureLongPress::pressed
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever a press goes unmoved/unreleased longer than what the GTK defaults tell.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate where the press happened, relative to the widget allocation

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate where the press happened, relative to the widget allocation

signal.name: GtkGesturePan::pan
signal.description: This signal is emitted once a panning gesture along the expected axis is detected.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: The object which received the signal

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: current direction of the pan gesture

property.name: GtkGesturePan:orientation
property.description: The expected orientation of pan gestures.

signal.name: GtkGestureRotate::angle-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted when the angle between both tracked points changes.

parameter.name: gesture
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: angle_delta
parameter.parameter_description: Difference with the starting angle, in radians

property.name: GtkGestureSingle:button
property.description: Mouse button number to listen to, or 0 to listen for any button.

property.name: GtkGestureSingle:exclusive
property.description: Whether the gesture is exclusive. Exclusive gestures only listen to pointer and pointer emulated events.

property.name: GtkGestureSingle:touch-only
property.description: Whether the gesture handles only touch events.

signal.name: GtkGestureStylus::down
signal.description: A signal emitted when the stylus touches the device.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the stylus event

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate of the stylus event

signal.name: GtkGestureStylus::motion
signal.description: A signal emitted when the stylus moves while touching the device.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the stylus event

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate of the stylus event

signal.name: GtkGestureStylus::proximity
signal.description: A signal emitted when the stylus is in proximity of the device.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the stylus event

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate of the stylus event

signal.name: GtkGestureStylus::up
signal.description: A signal emitted when the stylus no longer touches the device.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: the X coordinate of the stylus event

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y coordinate of the stylus event

signal.name: GtkGestureSwipe::swipe
signal.description: This signal is emitted when the recognized gesture is finished, velocity and direction are a product of previously recorded events.

parameter.name: velocity_x
parameter.parameter_description: velocity in the X axis, in pixels/sec

parameter.name: velocity_y
parameter.parameter_description: velocity in the Y axis, in pixels/sec

signal.name: GtkGestureZoom::scale-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted whenever the distance between both tracked sequences changes.

parameter.name: controller
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: scale
parameter.parameter_description: Scale delta, taking the initial state as 1:1

property.name: GtkGridLayout:baseline-row
property.description: The row to align to the baseline, when #GtkWidget:valign is set to %GTK_ALIGN_BASELINE.

property.name: GtkGridLayout:column-homogeneous
property.description: Whether all the columns in the grid have the same width.

property.name: GtkGridLayout:column-spacing
property.description: The amount of space between to consecutive columns.

property.name: GtkGridLayout:row-homogeneous
property.description: Whether all the rows in the grid have the same height.

property.name: GtkGridLayout:row-spacing
property.description: The amount of space between to consecutive rows.

property.name: GtkGridLayoutChild:column
property.description: The column to place the child in.

property.name: GtkGridLayoutChild:column-span
property.description: The number of columns the child spans to.

property.name: GtkGridLayoutChild:row
property.description: The row to place the child in.

property.name: GtkGridLayoutChild:row-span
property.description: The number of rows the child spans to.

signal.name: GtkGridView::activate
signal.description:
The ::activate signal is emitted when a cell has been activated by the user, usually via activating the GtkGridView|list.activate-item action.
This allows for a convenient way to handle activation in a gridview. See GtkListItem:activatable for details on how to use this signal.

property.name: GtkGridView:enable-rubberband
property.description: Allow rubberband selection

property.name: GtkGridView:factory
property.description: Factory for populating list items

property.name: GtkGridView:max-columns
property.description:
Maximum number of columns per row
If this number is smaller than GtkGridView:min-columns, that value is used instead.

property.name: GtkGridView:min-columns
property.description: Minimum number of columns per row

property.name: GtkGridView:model
property.description: Model for the items displayed

property.name: GtkGridView:single-click-activate
property.description: Activate rows on single click and select them on hover

property.name: GtkHeaderBar:decoration-layout
property.description:
The decoration layout for buttons. If this property is not set, the #GtkSettings:gtk-decoration-layout setting is used.
See gtk_header_bar_set_decoration_layout() for information about the format of this string.

property.name: GtkHeaderBar:show-title-buttons
property.description:
Whether to show title buttons like close, minimize, maximize.
Which buttons are actually shown and where is determined by the #GtkHeaderBar:decoration-layout property, and by the state of the window (e.g. a close button will not be shown if the window can't be closed).

signal.name: GtkIMContext::commit
signal.description: The ::commit signal is emitted when a complete input sequence has been entered by the user. This can be a single character immediately after a key press or the final result of preediting.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: str
parameter.parameter_description: the completed character(s) entered by the user

signal.name: GtkIMContext::delete-surrounding
signal.description: The ::delete-surrounding signal is emitted when the input method needs to delete all or part of the context surrounding the cursor.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: the character offset from the cursor position of the text to be deleted. A negative value indicates a position before the cursor.

parameter.name: n_chars
parameter.parameter_description: the number of characters to be deleted

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled.

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-changed
signal.description: The ::preedit-changed signal is emitted whenever the preedit sequence currently being entered has changed. It is also emitted at the end of a preedit sequence, in which case gtk_im_context_get_preedit_string() returns the empty string.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-end
signal.description: The ::preedit-end signal is emitted when a preediting sequence has been completed or canceled.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::preedit-start
signal.description: The ::preedit-start signal is emitted when a new preediting sequence starts.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIMContext::retrieve-surrounding
signal.description: The ::retrieve-surrounding signal is emitted when the input method requires the context surrounding the cursor. The callback should set the input method surrounding context by calling the gtk_im_context_set_surrounding() method.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if the signal was handled.

enum.name: GtkIconLookupFlags
enum.description: Used to specify options for gtk_icon_theme_lookup_icon()

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_REGULAR
parameter.parameter_description: Try to always load regular icons, even when symbolic icon names are given

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_FORCE_SYMBOLIC
parameter.parameter_description: Try to always load symbolic icons, even when regular icon names are given

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_LOOKUP_PRELOAD
parameter.parameter_description: Starts loading the texture in the background so it is ready when later needed.

property.name: GtkIconPaintable:file
property.description: The file representing the icon, if any.

property.name: GtkIconPaintable:icon-name
property.description: The icon name that was chosen during lookup.

property.name: GtkIconPaintable:is-symbolic
property.description: Whether the icon is symbolic or not.

enum.name: GtkIconSize
enum.description:
Built-in icon sizes.
Icon sizes default to being inherited. Where they cannot be inherited, text size is the default.
All widgets which use GtkIconSize set the normal-icons or large-icons style classes correspondingly, and let themes determine the actual size to be used with the -gtk-icon-size CSS property.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_SIZE_INHERIT
parameter.parameter_description: Keep the size of the parent element

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_SIZE_LARGE
parameter.parameter_description: Large size, for example in an icon view

signal.name: GtkIconTheme::changed
signal.description: Emitted when the current icon theme is switched or GTK detects that a change has occurred in the contents of the current icon theme.

property.name: GtkIconTheme:display
property.description: The display that this icon theme object is attached to.

property.name: GtkIconTheme:icon-names
property.description: The icon names that are supported by the icon theme.

property.name: GtkIconTheme:resource-path
property.description:
Resource paths that will be looked at when looking for icons, similar to search paths.
The resources are considered as part of the hicolor icon theme and must be located in subdirectories that are defined in the hicolor icon theme, such as `@path/16x16/actions/run.png`. Icons that are directly placed in the resource path instead of a subdirectory are also considered as ultimate fallback.

property.name: GtkIconTheme:search-path
property.description:
The search path for this icon theme.
When looking for icons, GTK will search for a subdirectory of one or more of the directories in the search path with the same name as the icon theme containing an index.theme file. (Themes from multiple of the path elements are combined to allow themes to be extended by adding icons in the user’s home directory.)

property.name: GtkIconTheme:theme-name
property.description:
The name of the icon theme that is being used.
Unless set to a different value, this will be the value of the #GtkSettings:gtk-icon-theme-name property of the #GtkSettings object associated to the display of the icontheme object.

enum.name: GtkIconThemeError
enum.description: Error codes for GtkIconTheme operations.

parameter.name: GTK_ICON_THEME_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: The icon specified does not exist in the theme

signal.name: GtkIconView::activate-cursor-item
signal.description:
A [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user activates the currently focused item.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control activation programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal are Space, Return and Enter.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::item-activated
signal.description: The ::item-activated signal is emitted when the method gtk_icon_view_item_activated() is called, when the user double clicks an item with the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %FALSE, or when the user single clicks an item when the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %TRUE. It is also emitted when a non-editable item is selected and one of the keys: Space, Return or Enter is pressed.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal include - Arrow keys which move by individual steps - Home/End keys which move to the first/last item - PageUp/PageDown which move by "pages" All of these will extend the selection when combined with the Shift modifier.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

signal.name: GtkIconView::select-all
signal.description:
A [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user selects all items.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-a.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::select-cursor-item
signal.description:
A [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user selects the item that is currently focused.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
There is no default binding for this signal.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::selection-changed
signal.description: The ::selection-changed signal is emitted when the selection (i.e. the set of selected items) changes.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::toggle-cursor-item
signal.description:
A [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user toggles whether the currently focused item is selected or not. The exact effect of this depend on the selection mode.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
There is no default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Space.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkIconView::unselect-all
signal.description:
A [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user unselects all items.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control selection programmatically.
The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Shift-a.

parameter.name: iconview
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

property.name: GtkIconView:activate-on-single-click
property.description: The activate-on-single-click property specifies whether the "item-activated" signal will be emitted after a single click.

property.name: GtkIconView:cell-area
property.description:
The #GtkCellArea used to layout cell renderers for this view.
