property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-application-prefer-dark-theme
property.description:
Whether the application prefers to use a dark theme. If a GTK theme includes a dark variant, it will be used instead of the configured theme.
Some applications benefit from minimizing the amount of light pollution that interferes with the content. Good candidates for dark themes are photo and video editors that make the actual content get all the attention and minimize the distraction of the chrome.
Dark themes should not be used for documents, where large spaces are white/light and the dark chrome creates too much contrast (web browser, text editor...).

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-cursor-blink
property.description:
Whether the cursor should blink.
Also see the #GtkSettings:gtk-cursor-blink-timeout setting, which allows more flexible control over cursor blinking.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-cursor-blink-timeout
property.description:
Time after which the cursor stops blinking, in seconds. The timer is reset after each user interaction.
Setting this to zero has the same effect as setting #GtkSettings:gtk-cursor-blink to %FALSE.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-decoration-layout
property.description:
This setting determines which buttons should be put in the titlebar of client-side decorated windows, and whether they should be placed at the left of right.
The format of the string is button names, separated by commas. A colon separates the buttons that should appear on the left from those on the right. Recognized button names are minimize, maximize, close, icon (the window icon) and menu (a menu button for the fallback app menu).
For example, "menu:minimize,maximize,close" specifies a menu on the left, and minimize, maximize and close buttons on the right.
Note that buttons will only be shown when they are meaningful. E.g. a menu button only appears when the desktop shell does not show the app menu, and a close button only appears on a window that can be closed.
Also note that the setting can be overridden with the #GtkHeaderBar:decoration-layout property.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-dialogs-use-header
property.description:
Whether builtin GTK dialogs such as the file chooser, the color chooser or the font chooser will use a header bar at the top to show action widgets, or an action area at the bottom.
This setting does not affect custom dialogs using GtkDialog directly, or message dialogs.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-enable-accels
property.description: Whether menu items should have visible accelerators which can be activated.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-enable-event-sounds
property.description:
Whether to play any event sounds at all.
See the [Sound Theme Specifications](http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/sound-theme-spec) for more information on event sounds and sound themes.
GTK itself does not support event sounds, you have to use a loadable module like the one that comes with libcanberra.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-enable-input-feedback-sounds
property.description:
Whether to play event sounds as feedback to user input.
See the [Sound Theme Specifications](http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/sound-theme-spec) for more information on event sounds and sound themes.
GTK itself does not support event sounds, you have to use a loadable module like the one that comes with libcanberra.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-enable-primary-paste
property.description: Whether a middle click on a mouse should paste the 'PRIMARY' clipboard content at the cursor location.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-entry-password-hint-timeout
property.description: How long to show the last input character in hidden entries. This value is in milliseconds. 0 disables showing the last char. 600 is a good value for enabling it.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-error-bell
property.description: When %TRUE, keyboard navigation and other input-related errors will cause a beep. Since the error bell is implemented using gdk_surface_beep(), the windowing system may offer ways to configure the error bell in many ways, such as flashing the window or similar visual effects.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-font-name
property.description: The default font to use. GTK uses the family name and size from this string.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-im-module
property.description:
Which IM (input method) module should be used by default. This is the input method that will be used if the user has not explicitly chosen another input method from the IM context menu. This also can be a colon-separated list of input methods, which GTK will try in turn until it finds one available on the system.
See #GtkIMContext.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-keynav-use-caret
property.description: Whether GTK should make sure that text can be navigated with a caret, even if it is not editable. This is useful when using a screen reader.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-long-press-time
property.description: The time for a button or touch press to be considered a "long press".

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-overlay-scrolling
property.description: Whether scrolled windows may use overlaid scrolling indicators. If this is set to %FALSE, scrolled windows will have permanent scrollbars.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-primary-button-warps-slider
property.description:
If the value of this setting is %TRUE, clicking the primary button in a #GtkRange trough will move the slider, and hence set the range’s value, to the point that you clicked. If it is %FALSE, a primary click will cause the slider/value to move by the range’s page-size towards the point clicked.
Whichever action you choose for the primary button, the other action will be available by holding Shift and primary-clicking, or (since GTK 3.22.25) clicking the middle mouse button.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-print-backends
property.description: A comma-separated list of print backends to use in the print dialog. Available print backends depend on the GTK installation, and may include "file", "cups", "lpr" or "papi".

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-print-preview-command
property.description:
A command to run for displaying the print preview. The command should contain a `%f` placeholder, which will get replaced by the path to the pdf file. The command may also contain a `%s` placeholder, which will get replaced by the path to a file containing the print settings in the format produced by gtk_print_settings_to_file().
The preview application is responsible for removing the pdf file and the print settings file when it is done.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-recent-files-enabled
property.description: Whether GTK should keep track of items inside the recently used resources list. If set to %FALSE, the list will always be empty.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-recent-files-max-age
property.description: The maximum age, in days, of the items inside the recently used resources list. Items older than this setting will be excised from the list. If set to 0, the list will always be empty; if set to -1, no item will be removed.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-sound-theme-name
property.description:
The XDG sound theme to use for event sounds.
See the [Sound Theme Specifications](http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/sound-theme-spec) for more information on event sounds and sound themes.
GTK itself does not support event sounds, you have to use a loadable module like the one that comes with libcanberra.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-titlebar-double-click
property.description:
This setting determines the action to take when a double-click occurs on the titlebar of client-side decorated windows.
Recognized actions are minimize, toggle-maximize, menu, lower or none.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-titlebar-middle-click
property.description:
This setting determines the action to take when a middle-click occurs on the titlebar of client-side decorated windows.
Recognized actions are minimize, toggle-maximize, menu, lower or none.

property.name: GtkSettings:gtk-titlebar-right-click
property.description:
This setting determines the action to take when a right-click occurs on the titlebar of client-side decorated windows.
Recognized actions are minimize, toggle-maximize, menu, lower or none.

property.name: GtkShortcut:action
property.description: The action that gets activated by this shortcut.

property.name: GtkShortcut:arguments
property.description: Arguments passed to activation.

property.name: GtkShortcut:trigger
property.description: The trigger that triggers this shortcut.

enum.name: GtkShortcutActionFlags
enum.description: List of flags that can be passed to action activation. More flags may be added in the future.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_ACTION_EXCLUSIVE
parameter.parameter_description: The action is the only action that can be activated. If this flag is not set, a future activation may select a different action.

property.name: GtkShortcutController:mnemonic-modifiers
property.description: The modifiers that need to be pressed to allow mnemonics activation.

property.name: GtkShortcutController:model
property.description: A list model to take shortcuts from

property.name: GtkShortcutController:scope
property.description: What scope the shortcuts will be handled in.

property.name: GtkShortcutLabel:accelerator
property.description: The accelerator that @self displays. See #GtkShortcutsShortcut:accelerator for the accepted syntax.

property.name: GtkShortcutLabel:disabled-text
property.description: The text that is displayed when no accelerator is set.

enum.name: GtkShortcutScope
enum.description: Describes where #GtkShortcuts added to a #GtkShortcutController get handled.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_SCOPE_LOCAL
parameter.parameter_description: Shortcuts are handled inside the widget the controller belongs to.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_SCOPE_MANAGED
parameter.parameter_description: Shortcuts are handled by the first ancestor that is a #GtkShortcutManager

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_SCOPE_GLOBAL
parameter.parameter_description: Shortcuts are handled by the root widget.

enum.name: GtkShortcutType
enum.description: GtkShortcutType specifies the kind of shortcut that is being described. More values may be added to this enumeration over time.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_ACCELERATOR
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a keyboard accelerator. The #GtkShortcutsShortcut:accelerator property will be used.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_PINCH
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a pinch gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_STRETCH
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a stretch gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_ROTATE_CLOCKWISE
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a clockwise rotation gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_ROTATE_COUNTERCLOCKWISE
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a counterclockwise rotation gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_TWO_FINGER_SWIPE_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a two-finger swipe gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_TWO_FINGER_SWIPE_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a two-finger swipe gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a gesture. The #GtkShortcutsShortcut:icon property will be used.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_SWIPE_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a swipe gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

parameter.name: GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE_SWIPE_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: The shortcut is a swipe gesture. GTK+ provides an icon and subtitle.

property.name: GtkShortcutsGroup:accel-size-group
property.description:
The size group for the accelerator portion of shortcuts in this group.
This is used internally by GTK, and must not be modified by applications.

property.name: GtkShortcutsGroup:height
property.description:
A rough measure for the number of lines in this group.
This is used internally by GTK, and is not useful for applications.

property.name: GtkShortcutsGroup:title
property.description: The title for this group of shortcuts.

property.name: GtkShortcutsGroup:title-size-group
property.description:
The size group for the textual portion of shortcuts in this group.
This is used internally by GTK, and must not be modified by applications.

property.name: GtkShortcutsGroup:view
property.description:
An optional view that the shortcuts in this group are relevant for. The group will be hidden if the #GtkShortcutsWindow:view-name property does not match the view of this group.
Set this to %NULL to make the group always visible.

property.name: GtkShortcutsSection:max-height
property.description: The maximum number of lines to allow per column. This property can be used to influence how the groups in this section are distributed across pages and columns. The default value of 15 should work in most cases.

property.name: GtkShortcutsSection:section-name
property.description: A unique name to identify this section among the sections added to the GtkShortcutsWindow. Setting the #GtkShortcutsWindow:section-name property to this string will make this section shown in the GtkShortcutsWindow.

property.name: GtkShortcutsSection:title
property.description: The string to show in the section selector of the GtkShortcutsWindow for this section. If there is only one section, you don't need to set a title, since the section selector will not be shown in this case.

property.name: GtkShortcutsSection:view-name
property.description:
A view name to filter the groups in this section by. See #GtkShortcutsGroup:view.
Applications are expected to use the #GtkShortcutsWindow:view-name property for this purpose.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:accel-size-group
property.description:
The size group for the accelerator portion of this shortcut.
This is used internally by GTK, and must not be modified by applications.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:accelerator
property.description:
The accelerator(s) represented by this object. This property is used if #GtkShortcutsShortcut:shortcut-type is set to #GTK_SHORTCUT_ACCELERATOR.
The syntax of this property is (an extension of) the syntax understood by gtk_accelerator_parse(). Multiple accelerators can be specified by separating them with a space, but keep in mind that the available width is limited. It is also possible to specify ranges of shortcuts, using ... between the keys. Sequences of keys can be specified using a + or & between the keys.
Examples: - A single shortcut: <ctl><alt>delete - Two alternative shortcuts: <shift>a Home - A range of shortcuts: <alt>1...<alt>9 - Several keys pressed together: Control_L&Control_R - A sequence of shortcuts or keys: <ctl>c+<ctl>x
Use + instead of & when the keys may (or have to be) pressed sequentially (e.g use t+t for 'press the t key twice').
Note that <, > and & need to be escaped as <, > and & when used in .ui files.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:action-name
property.description: A detailed action name. If this is set for a shortcut of type %GTK_SHORTCUT_ACCELERATOR, then GTK will use the accelerators that are associated with the action via gtk_application_set_accels_for_action(), and setting #GtkShortcutsShortcut:accelerator is not necessary.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:direction
property.description: The text direction for which this shortcut is active. If the shortcut is used regardless of the text direction, set this property to #GTK_TEXT_DIR_NONE.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:icon
property.description: An icon to represent the shortcut or gesture. This property is used if #GtkShortcutsShortcut:shortcut-type is set to #GTK_SHORTCUT_GESTURE. For the other predefined gesture types, GTK provides an icon on its own.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:icon-set
property.description: %TRUE if an icon has been set.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:shortcut-type
property.description: The type of shortcut that is represented.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:subtitle
property.description:
The subtitle for the shortcut or gesture.
This is typically used for gestures and should be a short, one-line text that describes the gesture itself. For the predefined gesture types, GTK provides a subtitle on its own.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:subtitle-set
property.description: %TRUE if a subtitle has been set.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:title
property.description: The textual description for the shortcut or gesture represented by this object. This should be a short string that can fit in a single line.

property.name: GtkShortcutsShortcut:title-size-group
property.description:
The size group for the textual portion of this shortcut.
This is used internally by GTK, and must not be modified by applications.

signal.name: GtkShortcutsWindow::close
signal.description:
The ::close signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user uses a keybinding to close the window.
The default binding for this signal is the Escape key.

signal.name: GtkShortcutsWindow::search
signal.description:
The ::search signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user uses a keybinding to start a search.
The default binding for this signal is Control-F.

property.name: GtkShortcutsWindow:section-name
property.description:
The name of the section to show.
This should be the section-name of one of the #GtkShortcutsSection objects that are in this shortcuts window.

property.name: GtkShortcutsWindow:view-name
property.description:
The view name by which to filter the contents.
This should correspond to the #GtkShortcutsGroup:view property of some of the #GtkShortcutsGroup objects that are inside this shortcuts window.
Set this to %NULL to show all groups.

property.name: GtkSignalAction:signal-name
property.description: The name of the signal to emit.

signal.name: GtkSignalListItemFactory::bind
signal.description:
The ::bind signal is emitted when a new #GtkListItem:item has been set on the @listitem and should be bound for use.
After this signal was emitted, the listitem might be shown in a #GtkListView or other list widget.
The #GtkSignalListItemFactory::unbind signal is the opposite of this signal and can be used to undo everything done in this signal.

signal.name: GtkSignalListItemFactory::setup
signal.description:
The ::setup signal is emitted when a new listitem has been created and needs to be setup for use. It is the first signal emitted for every listitem.
The #GtkSignalListItemFactory::teardown signal is the opposite of this signal and can be used to undo everything done in this signal.

signal.name: GtkSignalListItemFactory::teardown
signal.description:
The ::teardown signal is emitted when a listitem is about to be destroyed. It is the last signal ever emitted for this @listitem.
This signal is the opposite of the #GtkSignalListItemFactory::setup signal and should be used to undo everything done in that signal.

signal.name: GtkSignalListItemFactory::unbind
signal.description:
The ::unbind signal is emitted when a listitem has been removed from use in a list widget and its new #GtkListItem:item is about to be unset.
This signal is the opposite of the #GtkSignalListItemFactory::bind signal and should be used to undo everything done in that signal.

property.name: GtkSingleSelection:autoselect
property.description: If the selection will always select an item

property.name: GtkSingleSelection:can-unselect
property.description: If unselecting the selected item is allowed

property.name: GtkSingleSelection:model
property.description: The model being managed

property.name: GtkSingleSelection:selected
property.description: Position of the selected item

property.name: GtkSingleSelection:selected-item
property.description: The selected item

enum.name: GtkSizeGroupMode
enum.description: The mode of the size group determines the directions in which the size group affects the requested sizes of its component widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_SIZE_GROUP_BOTH
parameter.parameter_description: group affects both horizontal and vertical requisition

enum.name: GtkSizeRequestMode
enum.description: Specifies a preference for height-for-width or width-for-height geometry management.

property.name: GtkSliceListModel:model
property.description: Child model to take slice from

property.name: GtkSliceListModel:offset
property.description: Offset of slice

property.name: GtkSliceListModel:size
property.description: Maximum size of slice

property.name: GtkSortListModel:incremental
property.description: If the model should sort items incrementally

property.name: GtkSortListModel:model
property.description: The model being sorted

property.name: GtkSortListModel:pending
property.description: Estimate of unsorted items remaining

property.name: GtkSortListModel:sorter
property.description: The sorter for this model

enum.name: GtkSortType
enum.description: Determines the direction of a sort.

signal.name: GtkSorter::changed
signal.description:
This signal is emitted whenever the sorter changed. Users of the sorter should then update the sort order again via gtk_sorter_compare().
#GtkSortListModel handles this signal automatically.
Depending on the @change parameter, it may be possible to update the sort order without a full resorting. Refer to the #GtkSorterChange documentation for details.

enum.name: GtkSorterChange
enum.description: Describes changes in a sorter in more detail and allows users to optimize resorting.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_CHANGE_DIFFERENT
parameter.parameter_description: The sorter change cannot be described by any of the other enumeration values

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_CHANGE_INVERTED
parameter.parameter_description: The sort order was inverted. Comparisons that returned %GTK_ORDERING_SMALLER now return %GTK_ORDERING_LARGER and vice versa. Other comparisons return the same values as before.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_CHANGE_LESS_STRICT
parameter.parameter_description: The sorter is less strict: Comparisons may now return %GTK_ORDERING_EQUAL that did not do so before.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_CHANGE_MORE_STRICT
parameter.parameter_description: The sorter is more strict: Comparisons that did return %GTK_ORDERING_EQUAL may not do so anymore.

enum.name: GtkSorterOrder
enum.description: Describes the type of order that a #GtkSorter may describe.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_ORDER_PARTIAL
parameter.parameter_description: A partial order. Any #GtkOrdering is possible.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_ORDER_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: No order, all elements are considered equal. gtk_sorter_compare() will only return %GTK_ORDERING_EQUAL.

parameter.name: GTK_SORTER_ORDER_TOTAL
parameter.parameter_description: A total order. gtk_sorter_compare() will only return %GTK_ORDERING_EQUAL if an item is compared with itself. Two different items will never cause this value to be returned.

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::change-value
signal.description:
The ::change-value signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a value change.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal are Up/Down and PageUp and/PageDown.

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: scroll
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkScrollType to specify the speed and amount of change

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::input
signal.description:
The ::input signal can be used to influence the conversion of the users input into a double value. The signal handler is expected to use gtk_editable_get_text() to retrieve the text of the spinbutton and set @new_value to the new value.
The default conversion uses g_strtod().

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: new_value
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the new value

signal.return: %TRUE for a successful conversion, %FALSE if the input was not handled, and %GTK_INPUT_ERROR if the conversion failed.

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::output

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

signal.return: %TRUE if the value has been displayed

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::value-changed
signal.description: The ::value-changed signal is emitted when the value represented by @spinbutton changes. Also see the #GtkSpinButton::output signal.

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

signal.name: GtkSpinButton::wrapped
signal.description: The ::wrapped signal is emitted right after the spinbutton wraps from its maximum to minimum value or vice-versa.

parameter.name: spin_button
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

enum.name: GtkSpinButtonUpdatePolicy
enum.description: The spin button update policy determines whether the spin button displays values even if they are outside the bounds of its adjustment. See gtk_spin_button_set_update_policy().

parameter.name: GTK_UPDATE_ALWAYS
parameter.parameter_description: When refreshing your #GtkSpinButton, the value is always displayed

parameter.name: GTK_UPDATE_IF_VALID
parameter.parameter_description: When refreshing your #GtkSpinButton, the value is only displayed if it is valid within the bounds of the spin button's adjustment

enum.name: GtkSpinType
enum.description: The values of the GtkSpinType enumeration are used to specify the change to make in gtk_spin_button_spin().

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_STEP_FORWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Increment by the adjustments step increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_STEP_BACKWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Decrement by the adjustments step increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_PAGE_FORWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Increment by the adjustments page increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_PAGE_BACKWARD
parameter.parameter_description: Decrement by the adjustments page increment.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_HOME
parameter.parameter_description: Go to the adjustments lower bound.

parameter.name: GTK_SPIN_END
parameter.parameter_description: Go to the adjustments upper bound.

property.name: GtkStack:hhomogeneous
property.description: %TRUE if the stack allocates the same width for all children.

property.name: GtkStack:vhomogeneous
property.description: %TRUE if the stack allocates the same height for all children.

property.name: GtkStackPage:needs-attention
property.description: Sets a flag specifying whether the page requires the user attention. This is used by the #GtkStackSwitcher to change the appearance of the corresponding button when a page needs attention and it is not the current one.

enum.name: GtkStackTransitionType
enum.description:
These enumeration values describe the possible transitions between pages in a #GtkStack widget.
New values may be added to this enumeration over time.

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_SLIDE_LEFT_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Slide from left or right according to the children order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_SLIDE_UP_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: Slide from top down or bottom up according to the order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_UP
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page by sliding up

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page by sliding down

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page by sliding to the left

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page by sliding to the right

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_UNDER_UP
parameter.parameter_description: Uncover the new page by sliding up

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_UNDER_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: Uncover the new page by sliding down

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_UNDER_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Uncover the new page by sliding to the left

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_UNDER_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Uncover the new page by sliding to the right

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_UP_DOWN
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page sliding up or uncover the new page sliding down, according to order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_DOWN_UP
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page sliding down or uncover the new page sliding up, according to order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_LEFT_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page sliding left or uncover the new page sliding right, according to order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_OVER_RIGHT_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Cover the old page sliding right or uncover the new page sliding left, according to order

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_ROTATE_LEFT
parameter.parameter_description: Pretend the pages are sides of a cube and rotate that cube to the left

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_ROTATE_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Pretend the pages are sides of a cube and rotate that cube to the right

parameter.name: GTK_STACK_TRANSITION_TYPE_ROTATE_LEFT_RIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Pretend the pages are sides of a cube and rotate that cube to the left or right according to the children order

enum.name: GtkStateFlags
enum.description: Describes a widget state. Widget states are used to match the widget against CSS pseudo-classes. Note that GTK extends the regular CSS classes and sometimes uses different names.

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_PRELIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: Widget has a mouse pointer over it

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_BACKDROP
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in a background toplevel window

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_LTR
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in left-to-right text direction

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_DIR_RTL
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is in right-to-left text direction

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_VISITED
parameter.parameter_description: The location the widget points to has already been visited

parameter.name: GTK_STATE_FLAG_DROP_ACTIVE
parameter.parameter_description: Widget is highlighted as a drop target for DND

signal.name: GtkStatusbar::text-popped
signal.description: Is emitted whenever a new message is popped off a statusbar's stack.

parameter.name: statusbar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: context_id
parameter.parameter_description: the context id of the relevant message/statusbar

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the message that was just popped

signal.name: GtkStatusbar::text-pushed
signal.description: Is emitted whenever a new message gets pushed onto a statusbar's stack.

parameter.name: statusbar
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: context_id
parameter.parameter_description: the context id of the relevant message/statusbar

property.name: GtkStringFilter:expression
property.description: The expression to evaluate on item to get a string to compare with

property.name: GtkStringFilter:ignore-case
property.description: If matching is case sensitive

property.name: GtkStringFilter:match-mode
property.description: If exact matches are necessary or if substrings are allowed

property.name: GtkStringFilter:search
property.description: The search term

enum.name: GtkStringFilterMatchMode
enum.description: Specifies how search strings are matched inside text.

parameter.name: GTK_STRING_FILTER_MATCH_MODE_EXACT
parameter.parameter_description: The search string and text must match exactly.

parameter.name: GTK_STRING_FILTER_MATCH_MODE_SUBSTRING
parameter.parameter_description: The search string must be contained as a substring inside the text.

parameter.name: GTK_STRING_FILTER_MATCH_MODE_PREFIX
parameter.parameter_description: The text must begin with the search string.

property.name: GtkStringSorter:expression
property.description: The expression to evaluate on item to get a string to compare with

property.name: GtkStringSorter:ignore-case
property.description: If matching is case sensitive

enum.name: GtkStyleContextPrintFlags
enum.description: Flags that modify the behavior of gtk_style_context_to_string(). New values may be added to this enumeration.

parameter.name: GTK_STYLE_CONTEXT_PRINT_RECURSE
parameter.parameter_description: Print the entire tree of CSS nodes starting at the style context's node

parameter.name: GTK_STYLE_CONTEXT_PRINT_SHOW_STYLE
parameter.parameter_description: Show the values of the CSS properties for each node

parameter.name: GTK_STYLE_CONTEXT_PRINT_SHOW_CHANGE
parameter.parameter_description: Show information about what changes affect the styles

signal.name: GtkSwitch::activate
signal.description: The ::activate signal on GtkSwitch is an action signal and emitting it causes the switch to animate. Applications should never connect to this signal, but use the notify::active signal.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkSwitch::state-set
signal.description:
The ::state-set signal on GtkSwitch is emitted to change the underlying state. It is emitted when the user changes the switch position. The default handler keeps the state in sync with the #GtkSwitch:active property.
To implement delayed state change, applications can connect to this signal, initiate the change of the underlying state, and call gtk_switch_set_state() when the underlying state change is complete. The signal handler should return %TRUE to prevent the default handler from running.
Visually, the underlying state is represented by the trough color of the switch, while the #GtkSwitch:active property is represented by the position of the switch.

parameter.name: widget
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the new state of the switch

signal.return: %TRUE to stop the signal emission

property.name: GtkSwitch:active
property.description: Whether the #GtkSwitch widget is in its on or off state.

property.name: GtkSwitch:state
property.description: The backend state that is controlled by the switch. See #GtkSwitch::state-set for details.

enum.name: GtkSystemSetting
enum.description:
Values that can be passed to the GtkWidgetClass.system_setting_changed vfunc to indicate that a system setting has changed and widgets may need to drop caches, or react otherwise.
Most of the values correspond to #GtkSettings properties.
More values may be added over time.

parameter.name: GTK_SYSTEM_SETTING_FONT_CONFIG
parameter.parameter_description: The font configuration has changed in a way that requires text to be redrawn. This can be any of the #GtkSettings:gtk-xft-antialias, #GtkSettings:gtk-xft-hinting, #GtkSettings:gtk-xft-hintstyle, #GtkSettings:gtk-xft-rgba or #GtkSettings:gtk-fontconfig-timestamp settings

parameter.name: GTK_SYSTEM_SETTING_ICON_THEME
parameter.parameter_description: The icon theme has changed in a way that requires icons to be looked up again

signal.name: GtkText::activate
signal.description:
The ::activate signal is emitted when the user hits the Enter key.
The default bindings for this signal are all forms of the Enter key.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: The widget on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkText::backspace
signal.description:
The ::backspace signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
The default bindings for this signal are Backspace and Shift-Backspace.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::copy-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-c and Ctrl-Insert.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::cut-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::cut-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to cut the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-x and Shift-Delete.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::delete-from-cursor
signal.description:
The ::delete-from-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a text deletion.
If the @type is %GTK_DELETE_CHARS, GTK deletes the selection if there is one, otherwise it deletes the requested number of characters.
The default bindings for this signal are Delete for deleting a character and Ctrl-Delete for deleting a word.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the deletion, as a #GtkDeleteType

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @type units to delete

signal.name: GtkText::insert-at-cursor
signal.description:
The ::insert-at-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates the insertion of a fixed string at the cursor.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::insert-emoji
signal.description:
The ::insert-emoji signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to present the Emoji chooser for the @self.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-. and Ctrl-;

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @self, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifier does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. - Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines - Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs - Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

parameter.name: extend
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the move should extend the selection

signal.name: GtkText::paste-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::paste-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to paste the contents of the clipboard into the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-v and Shift-Insert.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::preedit-changed
signal.description: If an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkText::toggle-overwrite
signal.description:
The ::toggle-overwrite signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to toggle the overwrite mode of the self.
The default bindings for this signal is Insert.

parameter.name: self
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkText:attributes
property.description:
A list of Pango attributes to apply to the text of the self.
This is mainly useful to change the size or weight of the text.
The #PangoAttribute's @start_index and @end_index must refer to the #GtkEntryBuffer text, i.e. without the preedit string.

property.name: GtkText:extra-menu
property.description: A menu model whose contents will be appended to the context menu.

property.name: GtkText:im-module
property.description:
Which IM (input method) module should be used for this self. See #GtkIMContext.
Setting this to a non-%NULL value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the GtkSettings #GtkSettings:gtk-im-module property.

property.name: GtkText:input-hints
property.description: Additional hints (beyond #GtkText:input-purpose) that allow input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.

property.name: GtkText:input-purpose
property.description:
The purpose of this text field.
This property can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.
Note that setting the purpose to %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PASSWORD or %GTK_INPUT_PURPOSE_PIN is independent from setting #GtkText:visibility.

property.name: GtkText:invisible-char-set
property.description: Whether the invisible char has been set for the #GtkText.

property.name: GtkText:overwrite-mode
property.description: If text is overwritten when typing in the #GtkText.

property.name: GtkText:placeholder-text
property.description: The text that will be displayed in the #GtkText when it is empty and unfocused.

property.name: GtkText:tabs
property.description: A list of tabstops to apply to the text of the self.

property.name: GtkText:truncate-multiline
property.description: When %TRUE, pasted multi-line text is truncated to the first line.

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::apply-tag
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::apply-tag signal is emitted to apply a tag to a range of text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Applying actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them).
See also: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range the tag is applied to

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range the tag is applied to

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::begin-user-action
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::begin-user-action signal is emitted at the beginning of a single user-visible operation on a #GtkTextBuffer.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::changed
signal.description: The #GtkTextBuffer::changed signal is emitted when the content of a #GtkTextBuffer has changed.

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::delete-range
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::delete-range signal is emitted to delete a range from a #GtkTextBuffer.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them). The default signal handler revalidates the @start and @end iters to both point to the location where text was deleted. Handlers which run after the default handler (see g_signal_connect_after()) do not have access to the deleted text.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_delete().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range to be deleted

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range to be deleted

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::end-user-action
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::end-user-action signal is emitted at the end of a single user-visible operation on the #GtkTextBuffer.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace(), gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection(), gtk_text_buffer_backspace().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-child-anchor
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::insert-child-anchor signal is emitted to insert a #GtkTextChildAnchor in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to be placed after the inserted @anchor.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-paintable
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::insert-paintable signal is emitted to insert a #GdkPaintable in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to be placed after the inserted @paintable.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert_paintable().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::insert-text
signal.description:
The ::insert-text signal is emitted to insert text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Insertion actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @location iter (or has to revalidate it). The default signal handler revalidates it to point to the end of the inserted text.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_insert(), gtk_text_buffer_insert_range().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: text
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 text to be inserted

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of the inserted text in bytes

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::mark-deleted
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::mark-deleted signal is emitted as notification after a #GtkTextMark is deleted.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::mark-set
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::mark-set signal is emitted as notification after a #GtkTextMark is set.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_create_mark(), gtk_text_buffer_move_mark().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::modified-changed
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::modified-changed signal is emitted when the modified bit of a #GtkTextBuffer flips.
See also: gtk_text_buffer_set_modified().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::paste-done
signal.description: The paste-done signal is emitted after paste operation has been completed. This is useful to properly scroll the view to the end of the pasted text. See gtk_text_buffer_paste_clipboard() for more details.

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::redo
signal.description: The "redo" signal is emitted when a request has been made to redo the previously undone operation.

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::remove-tag
signal.description:
The #GtkTextBuffer::remove-tag signal is emitted to remove all occurrences of @tag from a range of text in a #GtkTextBuffer. Removal actually occurs in the default handler.
Note that if your handler runs before the default handler it must not invalidate the @start and @end iters (or has to revalidate them).
See also: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag().

parameter.name: textbuffer
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: the start of the range the tag is removed from

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: the end of the range the tag is removed from

signal.name: GtkTextBuffer::undo
signal.description: The "undo" signal is emitted when a request has been made to undo the previous operation or set of operations that have been grouped together.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:can-redo
property.description: The #GtkTextBuffer:can-redo property denotes that the buffer can reapply the last undone action.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:can-undo
property.description: The #GtkTextBuffer:can-undo property denotes that the buffer can undo the last applied action.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:cursor-position
property.description: The position of the insert mark (as offset from the beginning of the buffer). It is useful for getting notified when the cursor moves.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:enable-undo
property.description: The #GtkTextBuffer:enable-undo property denotes if support for undoing and redoing changes to the buffer is allowed.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:has-selection
property.description: Whether the buffer has some text currently selected.

property.name: GtkTextBuffer:text
property.description: The text content of the buffer. Without child widgets and images, see gtk_text_buffer_get_text() for more information.

enum.name: GtkTextDirection
enum.description: Reading directions for text.

enum.name: GtkTextExtendSelection
enum.description: Granularity types that extend the text selection. Use the #GtkTextView::extend-selection signal to customize the selection.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_EXTEND_SELECTION_WORD
parameter.parameter_description: Selects the current word. It is triggered by a double-click for example.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_EXTEND_SELECTION_LINE
parameter.parameter_description: Selects the current line. It is triggered by a triple-click for example.

property.name: GtkTextMark:left-gravity
property.description: Whether the mark has left gravity. When text is inserted at the mark’s current location, if the mark has left gravity it will be moved to the left of the newly-inserted text, otherwise to the right.

property.name: GtkTextMark:name
property.description: The name of the mark or %NULL if the mark is anonymous.

enum.name: GtkTextSearchFlags
enum.description:
Flags affecting how a search is done.
If neither #GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_VISIBLE_ONLY nor #GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_TEXT_ONLY are enabled, the match must be exact; the special 0xFFFC character will match embedded paintables or child widgets.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_VISIBLE_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Search only visible data. A search match may have invisible text interspersed.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_TEXT_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Search only text. A match may have paintables or child widgets mixed inside the matched range.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_SEARCH_CASE_INSENSITIVE
parameter.parameter_description: The text will be matched regardless of what case it is in.

property.name: GtkTextTag:accumulative-margin
property.description:
Whether the margins accumulate or override each other.
When set to %TRUE the margins of this tag are added to the margins of any other non-accumulative margins present. When set to %FALSE the margins override one another (the default).

property.name: GtkTextTag:background-rgba
property.description: Background color as a #GdkRGBA.

property.name: GtkTextTag:fallback
property.description:
Whether font fallback is enabled.
When set to %TRUE, other fonts will be substituted where the current font is missing glyphs.

property.name: GtkTextTag:font
property.description:
Font description as string, e.g. \"Sans Italic 12\".
Note that the initial value of this property depends on the internals of #PangoFontDescription.

property.name: GtkTextTag:font-features
property.description: OpenType font features, as a string.

property.name: GtkTextTag:foreground-rgba
property.description: Foreground color as a #GdkRGBA.

property.name: GtkTextTag:invisible
property.description:
Whether this text is hidden.
Note that there may still be problems with the support for invisible text, in particular when navigating programmatically inside a buffer containing invisible segments.

property.name: GtkTextTag:language
property.description:
The language this text is in, as an ISO code. Pango can use this as a hint when rendering the text. If not set, an appropriate default will be used.
Note that the initial value of this property depends on the current locale, see also gtk_get_default_language().

property.name: GtkTextTag:letter-spacing
property.description: Extra spacing between graphemes, in Pango units.

property.name: GtkTextTag:paragraph-background
property.description: The paragraph background color as a string.

property.name: GtkTextTag:paragraph-background-rgba
property.description: The paragraph background color as a #GdkRGBA.

property.name: GtkTextTag:strikethrough-rgba
property.description: This property modifies the color of strikeouts. If not set, strikeouts will use the foreground color.

property.name: GtkTextTag:strikethrough-rgba-set
property.description: If the #GtkTextTag:strikethrough-rgba property has been set.

property.name: GtkTextTag:underline-rgba
property.description:
This property modifies the color of underlines. If not set, underlines will use the foreground color.
If #GtkTextTag:underline is set to %PANGO_UNDERLINE_ERROR, an alternate color may be applied instead of the foreground. Setting this property will always override those defaults.

property.name: GtkTextTag:underline-rgba-set
property.description: If the #GtkTextTag:underline-rgba property has been set.

signal.name: GtkTextTagTable::tag-added
signal.description: Emitted every time a new tag is added in the #GtkTextTagTable.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkTextTagTable::tag-changed
signal.description: Emitted every time a tag in the #GtkTextTagTable changes.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: size_changed
parameter.parameter_description: whether the change affects the #GtkTextView layout.

signal.name: GtkTextTagTable::tag-removed
signal.description:
Emitted every time a tag is removed from the #GtkTextTagTable.
The @tag is still valid by the time the signal is emitted, but it is not associated with a tag table any more.

parameter.name: texttagtable
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

signal.name: GtkTextView::backspace
signal.description:
The ::backspace signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user asks for it.
The default bindings for this signal are Backspace and Shift-Backspace.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::copy-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::copy-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to copy the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-c and Ctrl-Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::cut-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::cut-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to cut the selection to the clipboard.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-x and Shift-Delete.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::delete-from-cursor
signal.description:
The ::delete-from-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a text deletion.
If the @type is %GTK_DELETE_CHARS, GTK+ deletes the selection if there is one, otherwise it deletes the requested number of characters.
The default bindings for this signal are Delete for deleting a character, Ctrl-Delete for deleting a word and Ctrl-Backspace for deleting a word backwards.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the deletion, as a #GtkDeleteType

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @type units to delete

signal.name: GtkTextView::extend-selection
signal.description: The ::extend-selection signal is emitted when the selection needs to be extended at @location.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: location
parameter.parameter_description: the location where to extend the selection

signal.return: %GDK_EVENT_STOP to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event. %GDK_EVENT_PROPAGATE to propagate the event further.

signal.name: GtkTextView::insert-at-cursor
signal.description:
The ::insert-at-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates the insertion of a fixed string at the cursor.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::insert-emoji
signal.description:
The ::insert-emoji signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to present the Emoji chooser for the @text_view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-. and Ctrl-;

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::move-cursor
signal.description:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement. If the cursor is not visible in @text_view, this signal causes the viewport to be moved instead.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically.
The default bindings for this signal come in two variants, the variant with the Shift modifier extends the selection, the variant without the Shift modifier does not. There are too many key combinations to list them all here. - Arrow keys move by individual characters/lines - Ctrl-arrow key combinations move by words/paragraphs - Home/End keys move to the ends of the buffer - PageUp/PageDown keys move vertically by pages - Ctrl-PageUp/PageDown keys move horizontally by pages

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

parameter.name: extend_selection
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the move should extend the selection

signal.name: GtkTextView::move-viewport
signal.description:
The ::move-viewport signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which can be bound to key combinations to allow the user to move the viewport, i.e. change what part of the text view is visible in a containing scrolled window.
There are no default bindings for this signal.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the movement, as a #GtkScrollStep

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of @step units to move

signal.name: GtkTextView::paste-clipboard
signal.description:
The ::paste-clipboard signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to paste the contents of the clipboard into the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-v and Shift-Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::preedit-changed
signal.description:
If an input method is used, the typed text will not immediately be committed to the buffer. So if you are interested in the text, connect to this signal.
This signal is only emitted if the text at the given position is actually editable.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::select-all
signal.description:
The ::select-all signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to select or unselect the complete contents of the text view.
The default bindings for this signal are Ctrl-a and Ctrl-/ for selecting and Shift-Ctrl-a and Ctrl-\ for unselecting.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::set-anchor
signal.description:
The ::set-anchor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user initiates setting the "anchor" mark. The "anchor" mark gets placed at the same position as the "insert" mark.
This signal has no default bindings.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::toggle-cursor-visible
signal.description:
The ::toggle-cursor-visible signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to toggle the #GtkTextView:cursor-visible property.
The default binding for this signal is F7.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

signal.name: GtkTextView::toggle-overwrite
signal.description:
The ::toggle-overwrite signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted to toggle the overwrite mode of the text view.
The default bindings for this signal is Insert.

parameter.name: text_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal

property.name: GtkTextView:bottom-margin
property.description:
The bottom margin for text in the text view.
Note that this property is confusingly named. In CSS terms, the value set here is padding, and it is applied in addition to the padding from the theme.
Don't confuse this property with #GtkWidget:margin-bottom.

property.name: GtkTextView:im-module
property.description:
Which IM (input method) module should be used for this text_view. See #GtkIMContext.
Setting this to a non-%NULL value overrides the system-wide IM module setting. See the GtkSettings #GtkSettings:gtk-im-module property.

property.name: GtkTextView:input-hints
property.description: Additional hints (beyond #GtkTextView:input-purpose) that allow input methods to fine-tune their behaviour.

property.name: GtkTextView:input-purpose
property.description:
The purpose of this text field.
This property can be used by on-screen keyboards and other input methods to adjust their behaviour.

property.name: GtkTextView:left-margin
property.description:
The default left margin for text in the text view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.
Note that this property is confusingly named. In CSS terms, the value set here is padding, and it is applied in addition to the padding from the theme.

property.name: GtkTextView:monospace
property.description: If %TRUE, set the .monospace style class on the text view to indicate that a monospace font is desired.

property.name: GtkTextView:right-margin
property.description:
The default right margin for text in the text view. Tags in the buffer may override the default.
Note that this property is confusingly named. In CSS terms, the value set here is padding, and it is applied in addition to the padding from the theme.

property.name: GtkTextView:top-margin
property.description:
The top margin for text in the text view.
Note that this property is confusingly named. In CSS terms, the value set here is padding, and it is applied in addition to the padding from the theme.
Don't confuse this property with #GtkWidget:margin-top.

property.name: GtkTextViewChild:window-type
property.description: The "window-type" property is the #GtkTextWindowType of the #GtkTextView that the child is attached.

enum.name: GtkTextViewLayer
enum.description: Used to reference the layers of #GtkTextView for the purpose of customized drawing with the ::snapshot_layer vfunc.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_VIEW_LAYER_BELOW_TEXT
parameter.parameter_description: The layer rendered below the text (but above the background).

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_VIEW_LAYER_ABOVE_TEXT
parameter.parameter_description: The layer rendered above the text.

enum.name: GtkTextWindowType
enum.description: Used to reference the parts of #GtkTextView.

parameter.name: GTK_TEXT_WINDOW_WIDGET
parameter.parameter_description: Window that floats over scrolling areas.

signal.name: GtkToggleButton::toggled
signal.description: Should be connected if you wish to perform an action whenever the #GtkToggleButton's state is changed.

parameter.name: togglebutton
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

property.name: GtkTreeExpander:child
property.description: The child widget with the actual contents

property.name: GtkTreeExpander:item
property.description: The item held by this expander's row

property.name: GtkTreeExpander:list-row
property.description: The list row to track for expander state

property.name: GtkTreeListModel:autoexpand
property.description: If all rows should be expanded by default

property.name: GtkTreeListModel:model
property.description: The root model displayed

property.name: GtkTreeListModel:passthrough
property.description: If %FALSE, the #GListModel functions for this object return custom #GtkTreeListRow objects. If %TRUE, the values of the child models are pass through unmodified.

property.name: GtkTreeListRow:children
property.description: The model holding the row's children.

property.name: GtkTreeListRow:depth
property.description: The depth in the tree of this row

property.name: GtkTreeListRow:expandable
property.description: If this row can ever be expanded

property.name: GtkTreeListRow:expanded
property.description: If this row is currently expanded

property.name: GtkTreeListRow:item
property.description: The item held in this row

property.name: GtkTreeListRowSorter:sorter
property.description: The underlying sorter

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-changed
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a row in the model has changed.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter-struct pointing to the changed row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-deleted
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when a row has been deleted.
Note that no iterator is passed to the signal handler, since the row is already deleted.
This should be called by models after a row has been removed. The location pointed to by @path should be the location that the row previously was at. It may not be a valid location anymore.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-has-child-toggled
signal.description: This signal is emitted when a row has gotten the first child row or lost its last child row.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter-struct pointing to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::row-inserted
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when a new row has been inserted in the model.
Note that the row may still be empty at this point, since it is a common pattern to first insert an empty row, and then fill it with the desired values.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter-struct pointing to the new row

signal.name: GtkTreeModel::rows-reordered
signal.description:
This signal is emitted when the children of a node in the #GtkTreeModel have been reordered.
Note that this signal is not emitted when rows are reordered by DND, since this is implemented by removing and then reinserting the row.

parameter.name: tree_model
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeModel on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a #GtkTreePath-struct identifying the tree node whose children have been reordered

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: a valid #GtkTreeIter-struct pointing to the node whose children have been reordered, or %NULL if the depth of @path is 0

parameter.name: new_order
parameter.parameter_description: an array of integers mapping the current position of each child to its old position before the re-ordering, i.e. @new_order`[newpos] = oldpos`

enum.name: GtkTreeModelFlags
enum.description:
These flags indicate various properties of a #GtkTreeModel.
They are returned by gtk_tree_model_get_flags(), and must be static for the lifetime of the object. A more complete description of #GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST can be found in the overview of this section.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_MODEL_ITERS_PERSIST
parameter.parameter_description: iterators survive all signals emitted by the tree

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_MODEL_LIST_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: the model is a list only, and never has children

signal.name: GtkTreeSelection::changed
signal.description: Emitted whenever the selection has (possibly) changed. Please note that this signal is mostly a hint. It may only be emitted once when a range of rows are selected, and it may occasionally be emitted when nothing has happened.

parameter.name: treeselection
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

property.name: GtkTreeSelection:mode
property.description: Selection mode. See gtk_tree_selection_set_mode() for more information on this property.

signal.name: GtkTreeSortable::sort-column-changed
signal.description: The ::sort-column-changed signal is emitted when the sort column or sort order of @sortable is changed. The signal is emitted before the contents of @sortable are resorted.

parameter.name: sortable
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::columns-changed
signal.description: The number of columns of the treeview has changed.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::cursor-changed
signal.description: The position of the cursor (focused cell) has changed.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GtkTreeView::move-cursor
signal.description:
The #GtkTreeView::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkSignalAction] which gets emitted when the user presses one of the cursor keys.
Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with g_signal_emit_by_name() if they need to control the cursor programmatically. In contrast to gtk_tree_view_set_cursor() and gtk_tree_view_set_cursor_on_cell() when moving horizontally #GtkTreeView::move-cursor does not reset the current selection.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted.

parameter.name: step
parameter.parameter_description: the granularity of the move, as a #GtkMovementStep. %GTK_MOVEMENT_LOGICAL_POSITIONS, %GTK_MOVEMENT_VISUAL_POSITIONS, %GTK_MOVEMENT_DISPLAY_LINES, %GTK_MOVEMENT_PAGES and %GTK_MOVEMENT_BUFFER_ENDS are supported. %GTK_MOVEMENT_LOGICAL_POSITIONS and %GTK_MOVEMENT_VISUAL_POSITIONS are treated identically.

parameter.name: direction
parameter.parameter_description: the direction to move: +1 to move forwards; -1 to move backwards. The resulting movement is undefined for all other values.

signal.return: %TRUE if @step is supported, %FALSE otherwise.

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-activated
signal.description:
The "row-activated" signal is emitted when the method gtk_tree_view_row_activated() is called, when the user double clicks a treeview row with the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %FALSE, or when the user single clicks a row when the "activate-on-single-click" property set to %TRUE. It is also emitted when a non-editable row is selected and one of the keys: Space, Shift+Space, Return or Enter is pressed.
For selection handling refer to the [tree widget conceptual overview][TreeWidget] as well as #GtkTreeSelection.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: column
parameter.parameter_description: the #GtkTreeViewColumn in which the activation occurred

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-collapsed
signal.description: The given row has been collapsed (child nodes are hidden).

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the collapsed row

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeView::row-expanded
signal.description: The given row has been expanded (child nodes are shown).

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the expanded row

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.name: GtkTreeView::test-collapse-row
signal.description: The given row is about to be collapsed (hide its children nodes). Use this signal if you need to control the collapsibility of individual rows.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the row to collapse

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.return: %FALSE to allow collapsing, %TRUE to reject

signal.name: GtkTreeView::test-expand-row
signal.description: The given row is about to be expanded (show its children nodes). Use this signal if you need to control the expandability of individual rows.

parameter.name: tree_view
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

parameter.name: iter
parameter.parameter_description: the tree iter of the row to expand

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a tree path that points to the row

signal.return: %FALSE to allow expansion, %TRUE to reject

property.name: GtkTreeView:activate-on-single-click
property.description: The activate-on-single-click property specifies whether the "row-activated" signal will be emitted after a single click.

property.name: GtkTreeView:fixed-height-mode
property.description: Setting the ::fixed-height-mode property to %TRUE speeds up #GtkTreeView by assuming that all rows have the same height. Only enable this option if all rows are the same height. Please see gtk_tree_view_set_fixed_height_mode() for more information on this option.

property.name: GtkTreeView:hover-expand
property.description:
Enables or disables the hover expansion mode of @tree_view. Hover expansion makes rows expand or collapse if the pointer moves over them.
This mode is primarily intended for treeviews in popups, e.g. in #GtkComboBox or #GtkEntryCompletion.

property.name: GtkTreeView:hover-selection
property.description:
Enables or disables the hover selection mode of @tree_view. Hover selection makes the selected row follow the pointer. Currently, this works only for the selection modes %GTK_SELECTION_SINGLE and %GTK_SELECTION_BROWSE.
This mode is primarily intended for treeviews in popups, e.g. in #GtkComboBox or #GtkEntryCompletion.

property.name: GtkTreeView:level-indentation
property.description: Extra indentation for each level.

property.name: GtkTreeView:show-expanders
property.description: %TRUE if the view has expanders.

signal.name: GtkTreeViewColumn::clicked
signal.description: Emitted when the column's header has been clicked.

property.name: GtkTreeViewColumn:cell-area
property.description:
The #GtkCellArea used to layout cell renderers for this column.
If no area is specified when creating the tree view column with gtk_tree_view_column_new_with_area() a horizontally oriented #GtkCellAreaBox will be used.

property.name: GtkTreeViewColumn:sort-column-id
property.description: Logical sort column ID this column sorts on when selected for sorting. Setting the sort column ID makes the column header clickable. Set to -1 to make the column unsortable.

enum.name: GtkTreeViewColumnSizing
enum.description: The sizing method the column uses to determine its width. Please note that %GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_AUTOSIZE are inefficient for large views, and can make columns appear choppy.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_GROW_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: Columns only get bigger in reaction to changes in the model

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_AUTOSIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Columns resize to be the optimal size every time the model changes.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_COLUMN_FIXED
parameter.parameter_description: Columns are a fixed numbers of pixels wide.

enum.name: GtkTreeViewDropPosition
enum.description: An enum for determining where a dropped row goes.

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_DROP_INTO_OR_BEFORE
parameter.parameter_description: dropped row becomes a child or is inserted before

parameter.name: GTK_TREE_VIEW_DROP_INTO_OR_AFTER
parameter.parameter_description: dropped row becomes a child or is inserted after

enum.name: GtkTreeViewGridLines
enum.description: Used to indicate which grid lines to draw in a tree view.

enum.name: GtkUnit
enum.description: See also gtk_print_settings_set_paper_width().

property.name: GtkVideo:autoplay
property.description: If the video should automatically begin playing.

property.name: GtkVideo:file
property.description: The file played by this video if the video is playing a file.

property.name: GtkVideo:loop
property.description: If new media files should be set to loop.

property.name: GtkVideo:media-stream
property.description: The media-stream played

property.name: GtkVolumeButton:use-symbolic
property.description: Whether to use symbolic icons as the icons. Note that if the symbolic icons are not available in your installed theme, then the normal (potentially colorful) icons will be used.
