function.description: Gets the expression that is evaluated to obtain strings from items.

function.name: gtk_string_sorter_get_ignore_case
function.description: Gets whether the sorter ignores case differences.

function.name: gtk_string_sorter_new
function.description:
Creates a new string sorter that compares items using the given @expression.
Unless an expression is set on it, this sorter will always compare items as invalid.

function.name: gtk_string_sorter_set_expression
function.description:
Sets the expression that is evaluated to obtain strings from items.
The expression must have the type G_TYPE_STRING.

function.name: gtk_string_sorter_set_ignore_case
function.description: Sets whether the sorter will ignore case differences.

function.name: gtk_style_context_add_class

parameter.name: class_name
parameter.parameter_description: class name to use in styling

function.name: gtk_style_context_add_provider
function.description:
Adds a style provider to @context, to be used in style construction. Note that a style provider added by this function only affects the style of the widget to which @context belongs. If you want to affect the style of all widgets, use gtk_style_context_add_provider_for_display().
Note: If both priorities are the same, a #GtkStyleProvider added through this function takes precedence over another added through gtk_style_context_add_provider_for_display().

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority of the style provider. The lower it is, the earlier it will be used in the style construction. Typically this will be in the range between %GTK_STYLE_PROVIDER_PRIORITY_FALLBACK and %GTK_STYLE_PROVIDER_PRIORITY_USER

function.name: gtk_style_context_add_provider_for_display
function.description:
Adds a global style provider to @display, which will be used in style construction for all #GtkStyleContexts under @display.
GTK uses this to make styling information from #GtkSettings available.
Note: If both priorities are the same, A #GtkStyleProvider added through gtk_style_context_add_provider() takes precedence over another added through this function.

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority of the style provider. The lower it is, the earlier it will be used in the style construction. Typically this will be in the range between %GTK_STYLE_PROVIDER_PRIORITY_FALLBACK and %GTK_STYLE_PROVIDER_PRIORITY_USER

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_border
function.description: Gets the border for a given state as a #GtkBorder.

parameter.name: border
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the border settings

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_color
function.description: Gets the foreground color for a given state.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the foreground color

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_display
function.description: Returns the #GdkDisplay to which @context is attached.

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_margin
function.description: Gets the margin for a given state as a #GtkBorder.

parameter.name: margin
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the margin settings

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_padding
function.description: Gets the padding for a given state as a #GtkBorder.

parameter.name: padding
parameter.parameter_description: return value for the padding settings

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_scale
function.description: Returns the scale used for assets.

function.name: gtk_style_context_get_state
function.description:
Returns the state used for style matching.
This method should only be used to retrieve the #GtkStateFlags to pass to #GtkStyleContext methods, like gtk_style_context_get_padding(). If you need to retrieve the current state of a #GtkWidget, use gtk_widget_get_state_flags().

function.name: gtk_style_context_has_class
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @context currently has defined the given class name.

function.name: gtk_style_context_lookup_color
function.description: Looks up and resolves a color name in the @context color map.

parameter.name: color
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the looked up color

function.return: %TRUE if @color_name was found and resolved, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_style_context_remove_class
function.description: Removes @class_name from @context.

function.name: gtk_style_context_remove_provider
function.description: Removes @provider from the style providers list in @context.

function.name: gtk_style_context_remove_provider_for_display
function.description: Removes @provider from the global style providers list in @display.

function.name: gtk_style_context_restore
function.description: Restores @context state to a previous stage. See gtk_style_context_save().

function.name: gtk_style_context_save
function.description:
Saves the @context state, so temporary modifications done through gtk_style_context_add_class(), gtk_style_context_remove_class(), gtk_style_context_set_state(), etc. can quickly be reverted in one go through gtk_style_context_restore().
The matching call to gtk_style_context_restore() must be done before GTK returns to the main loop.

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_display
function.description:
Attaches @context to the given display.
The display is used to add style information from “global” style providers, such as the display's #GtkSettings instance.
If you are using a #GtkStyleContext returned from gtk_widget_get_style_context(), you do not need to call this yourself.

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_scale
function.description: Sets the scale to use when getting image assets for the style.

function.name: gtk_style_context_set_state
function.description: Sets the state to be used for style matching.

function.name: gtk_style_context_to_string
function.description:
Converts the style context into a string representation.
The string representation always includes information about the name, state, id, visibility and style classes of the CSS node that is backing @context. Depending on the flags, more information may be included.
This function is intended for testing and debugging of the CSS implementation in GTK. There are no guarantees about the format of the returned string, it may change.

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: Flags that determine what to print

function.name: gtk_switch_get_active
function.description: Gets whether the #GtkSwitch is in its “on” or “off” state.
function.return: %TRUE if the #GtkSwitch is active, and %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_switch_get_state
function.description: Gets the underlying state of the #GtkSwitch.

function.name: gtk_switch_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkSwitch widget.

function.name: gtk_switch_set_active
function.description: Changes the state of @self to the desired one.

parameter.name: is_active
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if @self should be active, and %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gtk_switch_set_state
function.description:
Sets the underlying state of the #GtkSwitch.
Normally, this is the same as #GtkSwitch:active, unless the switch is set up for delayed state changes. This function is typically called from a #GtkSwitch::state-set signal handler.
See #GtkSwitch::state-set for details.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_assert_property
function.description: Checks whether a #GtkAccessible implementation has its accessible property set to the expected value, and raises an assertion if the condition is not satisfied.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_assert_relation
function.description: Checks whether a #GtkAccessible implementation has its accessible relation set to the expected value, and raises an assertion if the condition is not satisfied.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_assert_role
function.description: Checks whether a #GtkAccessible implementation has the given @role, and raises an assertion if the condition is failed.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_assert_state
function.description: Checks whether a #GtkAccessible implementation has its accessible state set to the expected value, and raises an assertion if the condition is not satisfied.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_check_property
function.description: Checks whether the accessible @property of @accessible is set to a specific value.
function.return: the value of the accessible property

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_check_relation
function.description: Checks whether the accessible @relation of @accessible is set to a specific value.
function.return: the value of the accessible relation

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_check_state
function.description: Checks whether the accessible @state of @accessible is set to a specific value.
function.return: the value of the accessible state

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_has_property
function.description: Checks whether the #GtkAccessible has @property set.
function.return: %TRUE if the @property is set in the @accessible

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_has_relation
function.description: Checks whether the #GtkAccessible has @relation set.
function.return: %TRUE if the @relation is set in the @accessible

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_has_role
function.description: Checks whether the #GtkAccessible:accessible-role of the accessible is @role.

function.name: gtk_test_accessible_has_state
function.description: Checks whether the #GtkAccessible has @state set.
function.return: %TRUE if the @state is set in the @accessible

function.name: gtk_test_init
function.description:
This function is used to initialize a GTK test program.
It will in turn call g_test_init() and gtk_init() to properly initialize the testing framework and graphical toolkit. It’ll also set the program’s locale to “C”. This is done to make test program environments as deterministic as possible.
Like gtk_init() and g_test_init(), any known arguments will be processed and stripped from @argc and @argv.

parameter.name: argcp
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the `argc` parameter of the main() function. Changed if any arguments were handled.

parameter.name: argvp
parameter.parameter_description: Address of the `argv` parameter of main(). Any parameters understood by g_test_init() or gtk_init() are stripped before return.

function.name: gtk_test_list_all_types
function.description: Return the type ids that have been registered after calling gtk_test_register_all_types().

parameter.name: n_types
parameter.parameter_description: location to store number of types

function.name: gtk_test_register_all_types
function.description:
Force registration of all core GTK object types.
This allowes to refer to any of those object types via g_type_from_name() after calling this function.

function.name: gtk_test_widget_wait_for_draw
function.description:
Enters the main loop and waits for @widget to be “drawn”. In this context that means it waits for the frame clock of @widget to have run a full styling, layout and drawing cycle.
This function is intended to be used for syncing with actions that depend on @widget relayouting or on interaction with the display server.

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_copy
function.description: Copies @src and returns a new #GtkTextAttributes.
function.return: a copy of @src, free with gtk_text_attributes_unref()

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_copy_values
function.description: Copies the values from @src to @dest so that @dest has the same values as @src. Frees existing values in @dest.

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_new
function.description: Creates a #GtkTextAttributes, which describes a set of properties on some text.

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count on @values.

function.name: gtk_text_attributes_unref
function.description: Decrements the reference count on @values, freeing the structure if the reference count reaches 0.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_add_mark
function.description:
Adds the mark at position @where. The mark must not be added to another buffer, and if its name is not %NULL then there must not be another mark in the buffer with the same name.
Emits the #GtkTextBuffer::mark-set signal as notification of the mark's initial placement.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_add_selection_clipboard
function.description: Adds @clipboard to the list of clipboards in which the selection contents of @buffer are available. In most cases, @clipboard will be the #GdkClipboard returned by gtk_widget_get_primary_clipboard() for a view of @buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be tagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be tagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag_by_name
function.description: Calls gtk_text_tag_table_lookup() on the buffer’s tag table to get a #GtkTextTag, then calls gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be tagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be tagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_backspace
function.description:
Performs the appropriate action as if the user hit the delete key with the cursor at the position specified by @iter. In the normal case a single character will be deleted, but when combining accents are involved, more than one character can be deleted, and when precomposed character and accent combinations are involved, less than one character will be deleted.
Because the buffer is modified, all outstanding iterators become invalid after calling this function; however, the @iter will be re-initialized to point to the location where text was deleted.

parameter.name: interactive
parameter.parameter_description: whether the deletion is caused by user interaction

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action
function.description:
Denotes the beginning of an action that may not be undone. This will cause any previous operations in the undo/redo queue to be cleared.
This should be paired with a call to gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action() after the irreversible action has completed.
You may nest calls to gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action() pairs.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action
function.description:
Called to indicate that the buffer operations between here and a call to gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action() are part of a single user-visible operation. The operations between gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action() can then be grouped when creating an undo stack. #GtkTextBuffer maintains a count of calls to gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() that have not been closed with a call to gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action(), and emits the “begin-user-action” and “end-user-action” signals only for the outermost pair of calls. This allows you to build user actions from other user actions.
The “interactive” buffer mutation functions, such as gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive(), automatically call begin/end user action around the buffer operations they perform, so there's no need to add extra calls if you user action consists solely of a single call to one of those functions.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_copy_clipboard
function.description: Copies the currently-selected text to a clipboard.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor
function.description: This is a convenience function which simply creates a child anchor with gtk_text_child_anchor_new() and inserts it into the buffer with gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor(). The new anchor is owned by the buffer; no reference count is returned to the caller of gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_mark
function.description:
Creates a mark at position @where. If @mark_name is %NULL, the mark is anonymous; otherwise, the mark can be retrieved by name using gtk_text_buffer_get_mark(). If a mark has left gravity, and text is inserted at the mark’s current location, the mark will be moved to the left of the newly-inserted text. If the mark has right gravity (@left_gravity = %FALSE), the mark will end up on the right of newly-inserted text. The standard left-to-right cursor is a mark with right gravity (when you type, the cursor stays on the right side of the text you’re typing).
The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned #GtkTextMark, so you can ignore the return value if you like. Marks are owned by the buffer and go away when the buffer does.
Emits the #GtkTextBuffer::mark-set signal as notification of the mark's initial placement.

parameter.name: left_gravity
parameter.parameter_description: whether the mark has left gravity

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_create_tag
function.description:
Creates a tag and adds it to the tag table for @buffer. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_tag_new() and then adding the tag to the buffer’s tag table. The returned tag is owned by the buffer’s tag table, so the ref count will be equal to one.
If @tag_name is %NULL, the tag is anonymous.
If @tag_name is non-%NULL, a tag called @tag_name must not already exist in the tag table for this buffer.
The @first_property_name argument and subsequent arguments are a list of properties to set on the tag, as with g_object_set().

parameter.name: tag_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the new tag, or %NULL

parameter.name: first_property_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of first property to set, or %NULL

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL-terminated list of property names and values

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_cut_clipboard
function.description: Copies the currently-selected text to a clipboard, then deletes said text if it’s editable.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete
function.description: Deletes text between @start and @end. The order of @start and @end is not actually relevant; gtk_text_buffer_delete() will reorder them. This function actually emits the “delete-range” signal, and the default handler of that signal deletes the text. Because the buffer is modified, all outstanding iterators become invalid after calling this function; however, the @start and @end will be re-initialized to point to the location where text was deleted.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_interactive
function.description: Deletes all editable text in the given range. Calls gtk_text_buffer_delete() for each editable sub-range of [@start,@end). @start and @end are revalidated to point to the location of the last deleted range, or left untouched if no text was deleted.

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.return: whether some text was actually deleted

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark
function.description: Deletes @mark, so that it’s no longer located anywhere in the buffer. Removes the reference the buffer holds to the mark, so if you haven’t called g_object_ref() on the mark, it will be freed. Even if the mark isn’t freed, most operations on @mark become invalid, until it gets added to a buffer again with gtk_text_buffer_add_mark(). Use gtk_text_mark_get_deleted() to find out if a mark has been removed from its buffer. The #GtkTextBuffer::mark-deleted signal will be emitted as notification after the mark is deleted.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark_by_name
function.description: Deletes the mark named @name; the mark must exist. See gtk_text_buffer_delete_mark() for details.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_delete_selection
function.description: Deletes the range between the “insert” and “selection_bound” marks, that is, the currently-selected text. If @interactive is %TRUE, the editability of the selection will be considered (users can’t delete uneditable text).

parameter.name: interactive
parameter.parameter_description: whether the deletion is caused by user interaction

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.return: whether there was a non-empty selection to delete

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action
function.description:
Denotes the end of an action that may not be undone. This will cause any previous operations in the undo/redo queue to be cleared.
This should be called after completing modifications to the text buffer after gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action() was called.
You may nest calls to gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action() pairs.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action
function.description: Should be paired with a call to gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action(). See that function for a full explanation.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_bounds
function.description: Retrieves the first and last iterators in the buffer, i.e. the entire buffer lies within the range [@start,@end).

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with first position in the buffer

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_can_redo
function.description: Gets whether there is a redoable action in the history.
function.return: %TRUE if there is an redoable action

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_can_undo
function.description: Gets whether there is an undoable action in the history.
function.return: %TRUE if there is an undoable action

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_char_count
function.description: Gets the number of characters in the buffer; note that characters and bytes are not the same, you can’t e.g. expect the contents of the buffer in string form to be this many bytes long. The character count is cached, so this function is very fast.
function.return: number of characters in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_enable_undo
function.description:
Gets whether the buffer is saving modifications to the buffer to allow for undo and redo actions.
See gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action() to create changes to the buffer that cannot be undone.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_end_iter
function.description: Initializes @iter with the “end iterator,” one past the last valid character in the text buffer. If dereferenced with gtk_text_iter_get_char(), the end iterator has a character value of 0. The entire buffer lies in the range from the first position in the buffer (call gtk_text_buffer_get_start_iter() to get character position 0) to the end iterator.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_has_selection
function.description: Indicates whether the buffer has some text currently selected.
function.return: %TRUE if the there is text selected

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_insert
function.description: Returns the mark that represents the cursor (insertion point). Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_get_mark() to get the mark named “insert”, but very slightly more efficient, and involves less typing.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_child_anchor
function.description: Obtains the location of @anchor within @buffer.

parameter.name: anchor
parameter.parameter_description: a child anchor that appears in @buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line
function.description: Initializes @iter to the start of the given line. If @line_number is greater than the number of lines in the @buffer, the end iterator is returned.
function.return: whether the exact position has been found

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line_index
function.description:
Obtains an iterator pointing to @byte_index within the given line. @byte_index must be the start of a UTF-8 character. Note bytes, not characters; UTF-8 may encode one character as multiple bytes.
If @line_number is greater than the number of lines in the @buffer, the end iterator is returned. And if @byte_index is off the end of the line, the iterator at the end of the line is returned.

parameter.name: byte_index
parameter.parameter_description: byte index from start of line

function.return: whether the exact position has been found

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_line_offset
function.description:
Obtains an iterator pointing to @char_offset within the given line. Note characters, not bytes; UTF-8 may encode one character as multiple bytes.
Before the 3.20 version, it was not allowed to pass an invalid location.
If @line_number is greater than the number of lines in the @buffer, the end iterator is returned. And if @char_offset is off the end of the line, the iterator at the end of the line is returned.

parameter.name: char_offset
parameter.parameter_description: char offset from start of line

function.return: whether the exact position has been found

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_mark
function.description: Initializes @iter with the current position of @mark.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset
function.description: Initializes @iter to a position @char_offset chars from the start of the entire buffer. If @char_offset is -1 or greater than the number of characters in the buffer, @iter is initialized to the end iterator, the iterator one past the last valid character in the buffer.

parameter.name: char_offset
parameter.parameter_description: char offset from start of buffer, counting from 0, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_line_count
function.description: Obtains the number of lines in the buffer. This value is cached, so the function is very fast.
function.return: number of lines in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_mark
function.description: Returns the mark named @name in buffer @buffer, or %NULL if no such mark exists in the buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_max_undo_levels
function.description: Gets the maximum number of undo levels to perform. If 0, unlimited undo actions may be performed. Note that this may have a memory usage impact as it requires storing an additional copy of the inserted or removed text within the text buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_modified
function.description: Indicates whether the buffer has been modified since the last call to gtk_text_buffer_set_modified() set the modification flag to %FALSE. Used for example to enable a “save” function in a text editor.
function.return: %TRUE if the buffer has been modified

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bound
function.description:
Returns the mark that represents the selection bound. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_get_mark() to get the mark named “selection_bound”, but very slightly more efficient, and involves less typing.
The currently-selected text in @buffer is the region between the “selection_bound” and “insert” marks. If “selection_bound” and “insert” are in the same place, then there is no current selection. gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bounds() is another convenient function for handling the selection, if you just want to know whether there’s a selection and what its bounds are.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_bounds
function.description: Returns %TRUE if some text is selected; places the bounds of the selection in @start and @end (if the selection has length 0, then @start and @end are filled in with the same value). @start and @end will be in ascending order. If @start and @end are NULL, then they are not filled in, but the return value still indicates whether text is selected.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with selection start

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator to initialize with selection end

function.return: whether the selection has nonzero length

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_selection_content
function.description: Get a content provider for this buffer. It can be used to make the content of @buffer available in a #GdkClipboard, see gdk_clipboard_set_content().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_slice
function.description: Returns the text in the range [@start,@end). Excludes undisplayed text (text marked with tags that set the invisibility attribute) if @include_hidden_chars is %FALSE. The returned string includes a 0xFFFC character whenever the buffer contains embedded images, so byte and character indexes into the returned string do correspond to byte and character indexes into the buffer. Contrast with gtk_text_buffer_get_text(). Note that 0xFFFC can occur in normal text as well, so it is not a reliable indicator that a paintable or widget is in the buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_start_iter
function.description: Initialized @iter with the first position in the text buffer. This is the same as using gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset() to get the iter at character offset 0.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_tag_table
function.description: Get the #GtkTextTagTable associated with this buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_get_text
function.description: Returns the text in the range [@start,@end). Excludes undisplayed text (text marked with tags that set the invisibility attribute) if @include_hidden_chars is %FALSE. Does not include characters representing embedded images, so byte and character indexes into the returned string do not correspond to byte and character indexes into the buffer. Contrast with gtk_text_buffer_get_slice().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert
function.description: Inserts @len bytes of @text at position @iter. If @len is -1, @text must be nul-terminated and will be inserted in its entirety. Emits the “insert-text” signal; insertion actually occurs in the default handler for the signal. @iter is invalidated when insertion occurs (because the buffer contents change), but the default signal handler revalidates it to point to the end of the inserted text.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_at_cursor
function.description: Simply calls gtk_text_buffer_insert(), using the current cursor position as the insertion point.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor
function.description: Inserts a child widget anchor into the text buffer at @iter. The anchor will be counted as one character in character counts, and when obtaining the buffer contents as a string, will be represented by the Unicode “object replacement character” 0xFFFC. Note that the “slice” variants for obtaining portions of the buffer as a string include this character for child anchors, but the “text” variants do not. E.g. see gtk_text_buffer_get_slice() and gtk_text_buffer_get_text(). Consider gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor() as a more convenient alternative to this function. The buffer will add a reference to the anchor, so you can unref it after insertion.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive
function.description:
Like gtk_text_buffer_insert(), but the insertion will not occur if @iter is at a non-editable location in the buffer. Usually you want to prevent insertions at ineditable locations if the insertion results from a user action (is interactive).
@default_editable indicates the editability of text that doesn't have a tag affecting editability applied to it. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive_at_cursor
function.description:
Calls gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive() at the cursor position.
@default_editable indicates the editability of text that doesn't have a tag affecting editability applied to it. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of text in bytes, or -1

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_markup
function.description: Inserts the text in @markup at position @iter. @markup will be inserted in its entirety and must be nul-terminated and valid UTF-8. Emits the #GtkTextBuffer::insert-text signal, possibly multiple times; insertion actually occurs in the default handler for the signal. @iter will point to the end of the inserted text on return.

parameter.name: markup
parameter.parameter_description: a nul-terminated UTF-8 string containing [Pango markup][PangoMarkupFormat]

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_paintable
function.description: Inserts an image into the text buffer at @iter. The image will be counted as one character in character counts, and when obtaining the buffer contents as a string, will be represented by the Unicode “object replacement character” 0xFFFC. Note that the “slice” variants for obtaining portions of the buffer as a string include this character for paintable, but the “text” variants do not. e.g. see gtk_text_buffer_get_slice() and gtk_text_buffer_get_text().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_range
function.description:
Copies text, tags, and paintables between @start and @end (the order of @start and @end doesn’t matter) and inserts the copy at @iter. Used instead of simply getting/inserting text because it preserves images and tags. If @start and @end are in a different buffer from @buffer, the two buffers must share the same tag table.
Implemented via emissions of the insert_text and apply_tag signals, so expect those.

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: another position in the same buffer as @start

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_range_interactive
function.description: Same as gtk_text_buffer_insert_range(), but does nothing if the insertion point isn’t editable. The @default_editable parameter indicates whether the text is editable at @iter if no tags enclosing @iter affect editability. Typically the result of gtk_text_view_get_editable() is appropriate here.

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: another position in the same buffer as @start

function.return: whether an insertion was possible at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags
function.description: Inserts @text into @buffer at @iter, applying the list of tags to the newly-inserted text. The last tag specified must be %NULL to terminate the list. Equivalent to calling gtk_text_buffer_insert(), then gtk_text_buffer_apply_tag() on the inserted text; gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags() is just a convenience function.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags_by_name
function.description: Same as gtk_text_buffer_insert_with_tags(), but allows you to pass in tag names instead of tag objects.

parameter.name: first_tag_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of a tag to apply to @text

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_move_mark
function.description: Moves @mark to the new location @where. Emits the #GtkTextBuffer::mark-set signal as notification of the move.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_move_mark_by_name
function.description: Moves the mark named @name (which must exist) to location @where. See gtk_text_buffer_move_mark() for details.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_new
function.description: Creates a new text buffer.

parameter.name: table
parameter.parameter_description: a tag table, or %NULL to create a new one

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_paste_clipboard
function.description:
Pastes the contents of a clipboard. If @override_location is %NULL, the pasted text will be inserted at the cursor position, or the buffer selection will be replaced if the selection is non-empty.
Note: pasting is asynchronous, that is, we’ll ask for the paste data and return, and at some point later after the main loop runs, the paste data will be inserted.

parameter.name: override_location
parameter.parameter_description: location to insert pasted text, or %NULL

parameter.name: default_editable
parameter.parameter_description: whether the buffer is editable by default

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_place_cursor
function.description: This function moves the “insert” and “selection_bound” marks simultaneously. If you move them to the same place in two steps with gtk_text_buffer_move_mark(), you will temporarily select a region in between their old and new locations, which can be pretty inefficient since the temporarily-selected region will force stuff to be recalculated. This function moves them as a unit, which can be optimized.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_redo
function.description: Redoes the next redoable action on the buffer, if there is one.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_all_tags
function.description: Removes all tags in the range between @start and @end. Be careful with this function; it could remove tags added in code unrelated to the code you’re currently writing. That is, using this function is probably a bad idea if you have two or more unrelated code sections that add tags.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_selection_clipboard
function.description: Removes a #GdkClipboard added with gtk_text_buffer_add_selection_clipboard().

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag_by_name
function.description: Calls gtk_text_tag_table_lookup() on the buffer’s tag table to get a #GtkTextTag, then calls gtk_text_buffer_remove_tag().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: one bound of range to be untagged

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: other bound of range to be untagged

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_select_range
function.description: This function moves the “insert” and “selection_bound” marks simultaneously. If you move them in two steps with gtk_text_buffer_move_mark(), you will temporarily select a region in between their old and new locations, which can be pretty inefficient since the temporarily-selected region will force stuff to be recalculated. This function moves them as a unit, which can be optimized.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_enable_undo
function.description:
Sets whether or not to enable undoable actions in the text buffer. If enabled, the user will be able to undo the last number of actions up to gtk_text_buffer_get_max_undo_levels().
See gtk_text_buffer_begin_irreversible_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_irreversible_action() to create changes to the buffer that cannot be undone.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_mark
function.description: Move the mark to the given position, if not @should_exist, create the mark.

parameter.name: left_gravity
parameter.parameter_description: if the mark is created by this function, gravity for the new mark

parameter.name: should_exist
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE, warn if the mark does not exist, and return immediately

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_max_undo_levels
function.description: Sets the maximum number of undo levels to perform. If 0, unlimited undo actions may be performed. Note that this may have a memory usage impact as it requires storing an additional copy of the inserted or removed text within the text buffer.

parameter.name: max_undo_levels
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of undo actions to perform

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_modified
function.description: Used to keep track of whether the buffer has been modified since the last time it was saved. Whenever the buffer is saved to disk, call gtk_text_buffer_set_modified (@buffer, FALSE). When the buffer is modified, it will automatically toggled on the modified bit again. When the modified bit flips, the buffer emits the #GtkTextBuffer::modified-changed signal.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_set_text
function.description: Deletes current contents of @buffer, and inserts @text instead. If @len is -1, @text must be nul-terminated. @text must be valid UTF-8.

function.name: gtk_text_buffer_undo
function.description: Undoes the last undoable action on the buffer, if there is one.

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_get_deleted
function.description: Determines whether a child anchor has been deleted from the buffer. Keep in mind that the child anchor will be unreferenced when removed from the buffer, so you need to hold your own reference (with g_object_ref()) if you plan to use this function — otherwise all deleted child anchors will also be finalized.
function.return: %TRUE if the child anchor has been deleted from its buffer

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_get_widgets
function.description:
Gets a list of all widgets anchored at this child anchor.
The order in which the widgets are returned is not defined.

parameter.name: out_len
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the length of the array

function.return: an array of widgets anchored at @anchor

function.name: gtk_text_child_anchor_new
function.description: Creates a new #GtkTextChildAnchor. Usually you would then insert it into a #GtkTextBuffer with gtk_text_buffer_insert_child_anchor(). To perform the creation and insertion in one step, use the convenience function gtk_text_buffer_create_child_anchor().

function.name: gtk_text_get_activates_default
function.description: Retrieves the value set by gtk_text_set_activates_default().
function.return: %TRUE if the self will activate the default widget

function.name: gtk_text_get_attributes
function.description: Gets the attribute list that was set on the self using gtk_text_set_attributes(), if any.
function.return: the attribute list, or %NULL if none was set.

function.name: gtk_text_get_buffer
function.description: Get the #GtkEntryBuffer object which holds the text for this self.

function.name: gtk_text_get_enable_emoji_completion
function.description: Returns whether Emoji completion is enabled for this GtkText widget.

function.name: gtk_text_get_extra_menu
function.description: Gets the menu model set with gtk_text_set_extra_menu().

function.name: gtk_text_get_input_hints
function.description: Gets the value of the #GtkText:input-hints property.

function.name: gtk_text_get_input_purpose
function.description: Gets the value of the #GtkText:input-purpose property.

function.name: gtk_text_get_invisible_char
function.description: Retrieves the character displayed in place of the real characters for entries with visibility set to false. Note that GTK does not compute this value unless it needs it, so the value returned by this function is not very useful unless it has been explicitly set with gtk_text_set_invisible_char()
function.return: the current invisible char, or 0, if @text does not show invisible text at all.

function.name: gtk_text_get_max_length
function.description:
Retrieves the maximum allowed length of the text in @self. See gtk_text_set_max_length().
This is equivalent to getting @self's #GtkEntryBuffer and calling gtk_entry_buffer_get_max_length() on it.
function.return: the maximum allowed number of characters in #GtkText, or 0 if there is no maximum.

function.name: gtk_text_get_overwrite_mode
function.description: Gets the value set by gtk_text_set_overwrite_mode().
function.return: whether the text is overwritten when typing.

function.name: gtk_text_get_placeholder_text
function.description: Retrieves the text that will be displayed when @self is empty and unfocused
function.return: a pointer to the placeholder text as a string. This string points to internally allocated storage in the widget and must not be freed, modified or stored. If no placeholder text has been set, %NULL will be returned.

function.name: gtk_text_get_propagate_text_width
function.description: Returns whether the #GtkText will grow and shrink with the content.
function.return: %TRUE if @self will propagate the text width

function.name: gtk_text_get_tabs
function.description: Gets the tabstops that were set on the self using gtk_text_set_tabs(), if any.
function.return: the tabstops, or %NULL if none was set.

function.name: gtk_text_get_text_length
function.description:
Retrieves the current length of the text in @self.
This is equivalent to getting @self's #GtkEntryBuffer and calling gtk_entry_buffer_get_length() on it.
function.return: the current number of characters in #GtkText, or 0 if there are none.

function.name: gtk_text_get_truncate_multiline
function.description: Returns whether the #GtkText will truncate multi-line text that is pasted into the widget

function.name: gtk_text_get_visibility
function.description: Retrieves whether the text in @self is visible. See gtk_text_set_visibility().
function.return: %TRUE if the text is currently visible

function.name: gtk_text_grab_focus_without_selecting
function.description:
Causes @self to have keyboard focus.
It behaves like gtk_widget_grab_focus(), except that it doesn't select the contents of @self. You only want to call this on some special entries which the user usually doesn't want to replace all text in, such as search-as-you-type entries.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_assign
function.description: Assigns the value of @other to @iter. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be assigned with `GtkTextIter i = j;`. The function is used by language bindings.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_char
function.description: Moves backward by one character offset. Returns %TRUE if movement was possible; if @iter was the first in the buffer (character offset 0), gtk_text_iter_backward_char() returns %FALSE for convenience when writing loops.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_chars
function.description: Moves @count characters backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn’t move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position(), but moves backward.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_find_char
function.description: Same as gtk_text_iter_forward_find_char(), but goes backward from @iter.

parameter.name: pred
parameter.parameter_description: function to be called on each character

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the previous line. Returns %TRUE if @iter could be moved; i.e. if @iter was at character offset 0, this function returns %FALSE. Therefore if @iter was already on line 0, but not at the start of the line, @iter is snapped to the start of the line and the function returns %TRUE. (Note that this implies that in a loop calling this function, the line number may not change on every iteration, if your first iteration is on line 0.)

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_lines
function.description: Moves @count lines backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn’t move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move backward

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_search

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: bitmask of flags affecting the search

parameter.name: match_start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: match_end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: limit
parameter.parameter_description: location of last possible @match_start, or %NULL for start of buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_start
function.description: Moves backward to the previous sentence start; if @iter is already at the start of a sentence, moves backward to the next one. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_starts
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_sentence_start() up to @count times, or until it returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward instead of backward.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_text_chars
function.description: Moves backward by @count text characters (paintables, widgets, etc. do not count as characters for this). Equivalent to moving through the results of gtk_text_iter_get_text(), rather than gtk_text_iter_get_slice().

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_to_tag_toggle
function.description: Moves backward to the next toggle (on or off) of the #GtkTextTag @tag, or to the next toggle of any tag if @tag is %NULL. If no matching tag toggles are found, returns %FALSE, otherwise %TRUE. Does not return toggles located at @iter, only toggles before @iter. Sets @iter to the location of the toggle, or the start of the buffer if no toggle is found.
function.return: whether we found a tag toggle before @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_cursor_position
function.description: Moves @iter forward to the previous visible cursor position. See gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count visible cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_backward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the previous visible line. Returns %TRUE if @iter could be moved; i.e. if @iter was at character offset 0, this function returns %FALSE. Therefore if @iter was already on line 0, but not at the start of the line, @iter is snapped to the start of the line and the function returns %TRUE. (Note that this implies that in a loop calling this function, the line number may not change on every iteration, if your first iteration is on line 0.)

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_lines
function.description: Moves @count visible lines backward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn’t move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves forward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move backward

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_start
function.description: Moves backward to the previous visible word start. (If @iter is currently on a word start, moves backward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_starts
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_visible_word_start() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_word_start
function.description: Moves backward to the previous word start. (If @iter is currently on a word start, moves backward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_backward_word_starts
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_backward_word_start() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_can_insert
function.description: Considering the default editability of the buffer, and tags that affect editability, determines whether text inserted at @iter would be editable. If text inserted at @iter would be editable then the user should be allowed to insert text at @iter. gtk_text_buffer_insert_interactive() uses this function to decide whether insertions are allowed at a given position.

parameter.name: default_editability
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if text is editable by default

function.return: whether text inserted at @iter would be editable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_compare
function.description: A qsort()-style function that returns negative if @lhs is less than @rhs, positive if @lhs is greater than @rhs, and 0 if they’re equal. Ordering is in character offset order, i.e. the first character in the buffer is less than the second character in the buffer.
function.return: -1 if @lhs is less than @rhs, 1 if @lhs is greater, 0 if they are equal

function.name: gtk_text_iter_copy
function.description: Creates a dynamically-allocated copy of an iterator. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be copied with a simple assignment (`GtkTextIter i = j;`). The function is used by language bindings.
function.return: a copy of the @iter, free with gtk_text_iter_free()

function.name: gtk_text_iter_editable
function.description:
Returns whether the character at @iter is within an editable region of text.
Non-editable text is “locked” and can’t be changed by the user via #GtkTextView. If no tags applied to this text affect editability, @default_setting will be returned.
You don’t want to use this function to decide whether text can be inserted at @iter, because for insertion you don’t want to know whether the char at @iter is inside an editable range, you want to know whether a new character inserted at @iter would be inside an editable range. Use gtk_text_iter_can_insert() to handle this case.

parameter.name: default_setting
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if text is editable by default

function.return: whether @iter is inside an editable range

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_line
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter points to the start of the paragraph delimiter characters for a line (delimiters will be either a newline, a carriage return, a carriage return followed by a newline, or a Unicode paragraph separator character). Note that an iterator pointing to the \n of a \r\n pair will not be counted as the end of a line, the line ends before the \r. The end iterator is considered to be at the end of a line, even though there are no paragraph delimiter chars there.
function.return: whether @iter is at the end of a line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter ends a sentence. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the end of a sentence.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_tag
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if @tag is toggled off at exactly this point. If @tag is %NULL, returns %TRUE if any tag is toggled off at this point.
Note that if gtk_text_iter_ends_tag() returns %TRUE, it means that @iter is at the end of the tagged range, but that the character at @iter is outside the tagged range. In other words, unlike gtk_text_iter_starts_tag(), if gtk_text_iter_ends_tag() returns %TRUE, gtk_text_iter_has_tag() will return %FALSE for the same parameters.
function.return: whether @iter is the end of a range tagged with @tag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_ends_word
function.description: Determines whether @iter ends a natural-language word. Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the end of a word

function.name: gtk_text_iter_equal
function.description: Tests whether two iterators are equal, using the fastest possible mechanism. This function is very fast; you can expect it to perform better than e.g. getting the character offset for each iterator and comparing the offsets yourself. Also, it’s a bit faster than gtk_text_iter_compare().
function.return: %TRUE if the iterators point to the same place in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_char
function.description: Moves @iter forward by one character offset. Note that images embedded in the buffer occupy 1 character slot, so gtk_text_iter_forward_char() may actually move onto an image instead of a character, if you have images in your buffer. If @iter is the end iterator or one character before it, @iter will now point at the end iterator, and gtk_text_iter_forward_char() returns %FALSE for convenience when writing loops.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_chars
function.description: Moves @count characters if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the new position of @iter is different from its original position, and dereferenceable (the last iterator in the buffer is not dereferenceable). If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of characters to move, may be negative

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position
function.description: Moves @iter forward by a single cursor position. Cursor positions are (unsurprisingly) positions where the cursor can appear. Perhaps surprisingly, there may not be a cursor position between all characters. The most common example for European languages would be a carriage return/newline sequence. For some Unicode characters, the equivalent of say the letter “a” with an accent mark will be represented as two characters, first the letter then a "combining mark" that causes the accent to be rendered; so the cursor can’t go between those two characters. See also the #PangoLogAttr-struct and pango_break() function.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_find_char

parameter.name: pred
parameter.parameter_description: a function to be called on each character

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the next line. If the iter is already on the last line of the buffer, moves the iter to the end of the current line. If after the operation, the iter is at the end of the buffer and not dereferenceable, returns %FALSE. Otherwise, returns %TRUE.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_lines
function.description: Moves @count lines forward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn’t move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves backward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move forward

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_search

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting how the search is done

parameter.name: match_start
parameter.parameter_description: return location for start of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: match_end
parameter.parameter_description: return location for end of match, or %NULL

parameter.name: limit
parameter.parameter_description: location of last possible @match_end, or %NULL for the end of the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end
function.description: Moves forward to the next sentence end. (If @iter is at the end of a sentence, moves to the next end of sentence.) Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_ends
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end() @count times (or until gtk_text_iter_forward_sentence_end() returns %FALSE). If @count is negative, moves backward instead of forward.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_text_chars
function.description: Moves forward by @count text characters (paintables, widgets, etc. do not count as characters for this). Equivalent to moving through the results of gtk_text_iter_get_text(), rather than gtk_text_iter_get_slice().

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_end
function.description: Moves @iter forward to the “end iterator,” which points one past the last valid character in the buffer. gtk_text_iter_get_char() called on the end iterator returns 0, which is convenient for writing loops.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_line_end
function.description: Moves the iterator to point to the paragraph delimiter characters, which will be either a newline, a carriage return, a carriage return/newline in sequence, or the Unicode paragraph separator character. If the iterator is already at the paragraph delimiter characters, moves to the paragraph delimiter characters for the next line. If @iter is on the last line in the buffer, which does not end in paragraph delimiters, moves to the end iterator (end of the last line), and returns %FALSE.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new location is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_to_tag_toggle
function.description: Moves forward to the next toggle (on or off) of the #GtkTextTag @tag, or to the next toggle of any tag if @tag is %NULL. If no matching tag toggles are found, returns %FALSE, otherwise %TRUE. Does not return toggles located at @iter, only toggles after @iter. Sets @iter to the location of the toggle, or to the end of the buffer if no toggle is found.
function.return: whether we found a tag toggle after @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_cursor_position
function.description: Moves @iter forward to the next visible cursor position. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_cursor_positions
function.description: Moves up to @count visible cursor positions. See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() for details.
function.return: %TRUE if we moved and the new position is dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_line
function.description: Moves @iter to the start of the next visible line. Returns %TRUE if there was a next line to move to, and %FALSE if @iter was simply moved to the end of the buffer and is now not dereferenceable, or if @iter was already at the end of the buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_lines
function.description: Moves @count visible lines forward, if possible (if @count would move past the start or end of the buffer, moves to the start or end of the buffer). The return value indicates whether the iterator moved onto a dereferenceable position; if the iterator didn’t move, or moved onto the end iterator, then %FALSE is returned. If @count is 0, the function does nothing and returns %FALSE. If @count is negative, moves backward by 0 - @count lines.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: number of lines to move forward

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_end
function.description: Moves forward to the next visible word end. (If @iter is currently on a word end, moves forward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_ends
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_visible_word_end() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_word_end
function.description: Moves forward to the next word end. (If @iter is currently on a word end, moves forward to the next one after that.) Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_forward_word_ends
function.description: Calls gtk_text_iter_forward_word_end() up to @count times.
function.return: %TRUE if @iter moved and is not the end iterator

function.name: gtk_text_iter_free
function.description: Free an iterator allocated on the heap. This function is intended for use in language bindings, and is not especially useful for applications, because iterators can simply be allocated on the stack.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_buffer
function.description: Returns the #GtkTextBuffer this iterator is associated with.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_bytes_in_line
function.description: Returns the number of bytes in the line containing @iter, including the paragraph delimiters.
function.return: number of bytes in the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_char
function.description: The Unicode character at this iterator is returned. (Equivalent to operator* on a C++ iterator.) If the element at this iterator is a non-character element, such as an image embedded in the buffer, the Unicode “unknown” character 0xFFFC is returned. If invoked on the end iterator, zero is returned; zero is not a valid Unicode character. So you can write a loop which ends when gtk_text_iter_get_char() returns 0.
function.return: a Unicode character, or 0 if @iter is not dereferenceable

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_chars_in_line
function.description: Returns the number of characters in the line containing @iter, including the paragraph delimiters.
function.return: number of characters in the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_child_anchor
function.description: If the location at @iter contains a child anchor, the anchor is returned (with no new reference count added). Otherwise, %NULL is returned.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_language
function.description:
Returns the language in effect at @iter.
If no tags affecting language apply to @iter, the return value is identical to that of gtk_get_default_language().

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line
function.description: Returns the line number containing the iterator. Lines in a #GtkTextBuffer are numbered beginning with 0 for the first line in the buffer.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line_index
function.description: Returns the byte index of the iterator, counting from the start of a newline-terminated line. Remember that #GtkTextBuffer encodes text in UTF-8, and that characters can require a variable number of bytes to represent.
function.return: distance from start of line, in bytes

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset
function.description: Returns the character offset of the iterator, counting from the start of a newline-terminated line. The first character on the line has offset 0.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_marks
function.description: Returns a list of all #GtkTextMark at this location. Because marks are not iterable (they don’t take up any "space" in the buffer, they are just marks in between iterable locations), multiple marks can exist in the same place. The returned list is not in any meaningful order.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_offset
function.description: Returns the character offset of an iterator. Each character in a #GtkTextBuffer has an offset, starting with 0 for the first character in the buffer. Use gtk_text_buffer_get_iter_at_offset() to convert an offset back into an iterator.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_paintable
function.description: If the element at @iter is a paintable, the paintable is returned (with no new reference count added). Otherwise, %NULL is returned.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_slice
function.description: Returns the text in the given range. A “slice” is an array of characters encoded in UTF-8 format, including the Unicode “unknown” character 0xFFFC for iterable non-character elements in the buffer, such as images. Because images are encoded in the slice, byte and character offsets in the returned array will correspond to byte offsets in the text buffer. Note that 0xFFFC can occur in normal text as well, so it is not a reliable indicator that a paintable or widget is in the buffer.

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at start of a range

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at end of a range

function.return: slice of text from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_tags
function.description: Returns a list of tags that apply to @iter, in ascending order of priority (highest-priority tags are last). The #GtkTextTag in the list don’t have a reference added, but you have to free the list itself.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_text
function.description: Returns text in the given range. If the range contains non-text elements such as images, the character and byte offsets in the returned string will not correspond to character and byte offsets in the buffer. If you want offsets to correspond, see gtk_text_iter_get_slice().

parameter.name: start
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at start of a range

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: iterator at end of a range

function.return: array of characters from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_toggled_tags
function.description: Returns a list of #GtkTextTag that are toggled on or off at this point. (If @toggled_on is %TRUE, the list contains tags that are toggled on.) If a tag is toggled on at @iter, then some non-empty range of characters following @iter has that tag applied to it. If a tag is toggled off, then some non-empty range following @iter does not have the tag applied to it.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_line_index
function.description: Returns the number of bytes from the start of the line to the given @iter, not counting bytes that are invisible due to tags with the “invisible” flag toggled on.
function.return: byte index of @iter with respect to the start of the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_line_offset
function.description: Returns the offset in characters from the start of the line to the given @iter, not counting characters that are invisible due to tags with the “invisible” flag toggled on.
function.return: offset in visible characters from the start of the line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_slice
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_get_slice(), but invisible text is not included. Invisible text is usually invisible because a #GtkTextTag with the “invisible” attribute turned on has been applied to it.
function.return: slice of text from the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_get_visible_text
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_get_text(), but invisible text is not included. Invisible text is usually invisible because a #GtkTextTag with the “invisible” attribute turned on has been applied to it.
function.return: string containing visible text in the range

function.name: gtk_text_iter_has_tag
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter points to a character that is part of a range tagged with @tag. See also gtk_text_iter_starts_tag() and gtk_text_iter_ends_tag().

function.name: gtk_text_iter_in_range
function.description: Checks whether @iter falls in the range [@start, @end). @start and @end must be in ascending order.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_inside_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter is inside a sentence (as opposed to in between two sentences, e.g. after a period and before the first letter of the next sentence). Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).

function.name: gtk_text_iter_inside_word
function.description:
Determines whether the character pointed by @iter is part of a natural-language word (as opposed to say inside some whitespace). Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
Note that if gtk_text_iter_starts_word() returns %TRUE, then this function returns %TRUE too, since @iter points to the first character of the word.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_cursor_position
function.description: See gtk_text_iter_forward_cursor_position() or #PangoLogAttr or pango_break() for details on what a cursor position is.
function.return: %TRUE if the cursor can be placed at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_end
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter is the end iterator, i.e. one past the last dereferenceable iterator in the buffer. gtk_text_iter_is_end() is the most efficient way to check whether an iterator is the end iterator.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_is_start
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter is the first iterator in the buffer, that is if @iter has a character offset of 0.
function.return: whether @iter is the first in the buffer

function.name: gtk_text_iter_order
function.description: Swaps the value of @first and @second if @second comes before @first in the buffer. That is, ensures that @first and @second are in sequence. Most text buffer functions that take a range call this automatically on your behalf, so there’s no real reason to call it yourself in those cases. There are some exceptions, such as gtk_text_iter_in_range(), that expect a pre-sorted range.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_line
gtk_text_iter_set_line_index
function.description: Same as gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset(), but works with a byte index. The given byte index must be at the start of a character, it can’t be in the middle of a UTF-8 encoded character.

parameter.name: byte_on_line
parameter.parameter_description: a byte index relative to the start of @iter’s current line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset
function.description: Moves @iter within a line, to a new character (not byte) offset. The given character offset must be less than or equal to the number of characters in the line; if equal, @iter moves to the start of the next line. See gtk_text_iter_set_line_index() if you have a byte index rather than a character offset.

parameter.name: char_on_line
parameter.parameter_description: a character offset relative to the start of @iter’s current line

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_offset
function.description: Sets @iter to point to @char_offset. @char_offset counts from the start of the entire text buffer, starting with 0.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_visible_line_index
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_set_line_index(), but the index is in visible bytes, i.e. text with a tag making it invisible is not counted in the index.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_set_visible_line_offset
function.description: Like gtk_text_iter_set_line_offset(), but the offset is in visible characters, i.e. text with a tag making it invisible is not counted in the offset.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_line
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @iter begins a paragraph, i.e. if gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset() would return 0. However this function is potentially more efficient than gtk_text_iter_get_line_offset() because it doesn’t have to compute the offset, it just has to see whether it’s 0.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_sentence
function.description: Determines whether @iter begins a sentence. Sentence boundaries are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango text boundary algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the start of a sentence.

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_tag
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if @tag is toggled on at exactly this point. If @tag is %NULL, returns %TRUE if any tag is toggled on at this point.
Note that if gtk_text_iter_starts_tag() returns %TRUE, it means that @iter is at the beginning of the tagged range, and that the character at @iter is inside the tagged range. In other words, unlike gtk_text_iter_ends_tag(), if gtk_text_iter_starts_tag() returns %TRUE, gtk_text_iter_has_tag() will also return %TRUE for the same parameters.
function.return: whether @iter is the start of a range tagged with @tag

function.name: gtk_text_iter_starts_word
function.description: Determines whether @iter begins a natural-language word. Word breaks are determined by Pango and should be correct for nearly any language (if not, the correct fix would be to the Pango word break algorithms).
function.return: %TRUE if @iter is at the start of a word

function.name: gtk_text_iter_toggles_tag
function.return: whether @tag is toggled on or off at @iter

function.name: gtk_text_layout_clamp_iter_to_vrange
function.description: If the iterator is not fully in the range @top <= y < @bottom, then, if possible, move it the minimum distance so that the iterator in this range.
function.return: %TRUE if the iterator was moved, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_buffer
function.description: Gets the text buffer used by the layout. See gtk_text_layout_set_buffer().
function.return: the text buffer used by the layout.

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_cursor_locations
function.description: Given an iterator within a text layout, determine the positions of the strong and weak cursors if the insertion point is at that iterator. The position of each cursor is stored as a zero-width rectangle. The strong cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality equal to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted. The weak cursor location is the location where characters of the directionality opposite to the base direction of the paragraph are inserted.

parameter.name: strong_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the strong cursor position, or %NULL

parameter.name: weak_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the weak cursor position, or %NULL

function.name: gtk_text_layout_get_cursor_visible
function.description: Returns whether the insertion cursor will be shown.
